RATING: 9.5
Probably my favourite deception game of all time. I grew up playing Mafia/Werewolf, and when I discovered this, it was love at first sight. 

I always dislike the way mafia tends to boil down into the detective just telling all of the players what to do, and The Resistance largely removes that omniscient character. The deduction is there and information is plentiful, but also easy to falsify.

I can't say enough good things about this game!!

RATING: 9.5
One of the best gaming experiences I have had was playing The Resistance with a group of eight, half of whom I knew well and the other half I had just met. 
The game was intense and humorous at the same time. The tension was thick but it was so funny to watch people I know (who are terrible liars) try to deceive me and each other. 
Everyone had a blast that night with this game.
I have since tried it on my family during my birthday and it was not as well received.
Thankfully I have the positive experience to go on as well or I wouldn't know what this game can do.

RATING: 10
The first night I played it my group seemed a little apprehensive and didn't think they'd like it. We then proceeded to play it another six times back to back. It was the first game requested at the following games night and it completely dominated the playlist. It has been requested every single game night since then.
After each game people were enthusiastically discussing strategy and running down play-by-play analysis of each and every decision made and really thinking about how and why things worked the way they did.

Clearly it's doing something right.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I bought this as my first modern board game, with the idea of playing it with my friends in school between classes. We also invite some other classmates to play if they have some free time.

Everyone has loved it! The idea of getting as much information as you can when you are a resistance member, or doing your best at lying when you are a spy is amazing. The best part is that, as you can't decide your alliance nor be sure of the others' one, it's extremely rare for two plays to be the same.

The only problem is that spies win too often, especially if the players are good liars. But even if the game is kind of unbalanced it is always fun to play it, just to see your friends shouting and distrusting everyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I don't usually enjoy social deduction games, but this is for sure the best one I've played so far. My biggest complaint about this kind of game is the usual absence of a solid mechanic beneath all the talking, lying and bluffing... which makes the game-play too intangible - so to speak - for me, since the players can only rely on their ability to read other people's faces.

The Resistance is different, even if it's still really simple and straight-forward. The key to its trick is the addition of the voting phase, because it really allows to read the other players's intentions and brings a huge deal of discussion to the table every time. This simple mechanic makes the game very deep and interesting! I also like the fact that all the players are involved at all times... unlike Werewolf, a game which is often compared to Resistance, where players are killed off turn by turn.

The Resistance is a really great game... and one I'm growing more fond of play after play. The Avalon version introduces some really cool roles, that make thing even more interesting and even more tense! Finally I've found the social deduction game that I enjoy. Huge thumbs up for me!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Hasn't gone well yet.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wow, just wow. This is one of the greatest party games that I've been introduced to. All of the suspicion, accusation, finger-pointing and treachery of a game like BSG or SOC, but all turns are taken together and everyone is involves in every play. After learning the rules, my friends and I were completing a game in 20 mins and coming back for more.

The only markdown is on balance.  In standard rules, the spys win very regularly. Even with a slight imbalance, it was a blast seeing how each game would play out. If you're interested in a more balanced game I'd recommend playing the 'blind spy' variant. 

EDIT:
I retract my imbalance comment towards spies. Turns out we were just doing it wrong. Remember people, vote teams down!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The secret traitor mechanic is implemented intuitively and can be fun as long as you get into the game--make sure to accuse people and get the ball rolling! However, I really don't prefer the standard rules where spies know one another (standard rules as written). I've played many games where the spies didn't know one another... and they still won most of the time. The 'blind spies' variant in the rulebook makes the dynamics so much more fun IMO.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pros
- Lying to someone else's face
- Not lying to someone's face and they think you are 
- Trying to figure out who's lying to your face
- Knowing someone is a spy, but nobody will believe you even though you know they are
- Trying to figure out if you or your spy teammate is going to fail this mission
- Knowing that your team already lost because you weren't on the last mission
- Seeing someone's loyalty card and knowing they are on your team
- Seeing someone's card and lying to everybody that they are a spy
- Components and cards are great 

Cons
- Drunk people are difficult to teach this game to, I've learned 
- Someone who is shy or timid might get lost in the shuffle in larger games by outspoken people 
- Might have to sleeve loyalty cards to avoid marks

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This would probably be my favorite social deduction game, except that the math of the situation seems too limiting. The low numbers of participants in each mission really narrows the deduction down on the right people and, due to that, the game is constrained to a pretty short ride. That prevents it from being like Spyfall, and allowing people to just keep on playing it over and over.

I'd prefer something that does a better job of evoking the theme of going on missions, as resistance fighters, and which gave a strong feeling of an extended campaign to root out the traitors and also fight the good fight. As it is, it feels too tightly constrained to do exactly one thing, for five minutes, and then you're done with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The Resistance is one of those games that with the right group of people it is a blast but in another group it might not work as well. I've played games with both and the experience has been very different but thankfully I have played more "good" games of The Resistance than "bad" ones. 

I really like the way that the game isn't really a puzzle that you can solve. Sure there are strategies for the spies and the rebels to help their side win but ultimately a lot of it comes down to how the individual player reacts.

A great party game that has theme, interaction and short-play time going for it! Much better than Werewolf!

Edit: My love for "The Resistance" has waned somewhat over time but that could just be a result of the group I play it with. I find it can be too shouty and too prone to "groupthink" with no actual evidence to back up accusations. It also kind of sucks if you get dealt the same role again and again. This is just the bad luck of the draw but it can still get stale quickly if this happens.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
5-10(7)

UPDATE: The Avalon roles do way way more to keep this game lively than the plot cards ever did. Highly recommended.

-------------------------------------------------

UPDATE: A lot more interesting with the plot cards, on account of it's not merely just an interesting smoke-and-mirrors "he said she said" game, but rather something where information gets introduced into the game. I think it also improves the balance. A great social activity.

---------------------------------------------------------

Played with five, which worked really well.

For what it is, this is excellent. We played this over and over. An effective traitor game where you have multiple means of gathering information: mission failure, team selection, and voting for the teams. Spies will often vote in bloc, and often conspicuously, say.

At points, the first rounds feel "throwaway" in that spies are too anxious to sabotage, and are sort of waiting for later rounds (in which the rebels have to choose their teams perfectly). But then, there is still team selection and voting (even if the missions pass). Given that spies know who each other are, their behavior can be noticeably different (and susceptible to groupthink).

Certain weaknesses are that it can depend a lot of the social elements and the dissembling, which may make it unenjoyable or difficult for some players. Also, some games can be right routs if the spies tip too early (though it's their fault!) or if the rebels just happen to stumble into winning teams. But with quick gameplay, I can't say that it ruins the experience at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Party Deduction
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I've been playing this every weekend for more than 5 months and I still find new deception tactics in every game. Some people say it's best for 5, 7, 9. My personal fav is 6 or 9. With its simple mechanics, it has incredible deduction/accusation logic under the hood. Each setup requires its own approach and modelling of all possible situations in advance. If you're a spy, you've got to plan your offensive and chaos-making strategies. If you're a good guy, you've got to predict spy behaviors, plan the tactics of keeping the group with a cold head. Either require strong emotional readiness for defensive situations.

P.S. Hidden Agenda (Avalon roles) are highly recommended.

RATING: 7.5
[ESP] Entretenido juego al estilo de Werewulf. Algunos jugadores son la resistencia mientras que otros son espías que intentan derrotarlos. Los espías se conocen entre sí. 
En cada operación un lider nominará a los participantes y todos deberán votar secretamentesi quieren o no que ese sea el equipo que vaya a la misión. Si se aprueba el equipo entonces solo los miembros de este deberán votar, nuevamente en secreto, por si la misión es exitosa o no.
el primer equipo que logre 3 victorias será el ganador.

RATING: 10

RATING: 7
*First edition copy*
I just got a chance to play it a few times. Great game. It could be better with the right folks though. One friend thought it was best to accuse me of being the spy all the time.  We also had an issue with a member of the resistance choosing a mission fail card. My only beef with the game was that the minimal symbolism on the cards isn't completely clear. Yes, no, pass, fail would have been cool on the card. Maybe this is blasphemy, but I just used a sharpie and wrote the words on the cards. The second edition deals with this by having those words on the card.  Otherwise, excellent part quality. I

 The plot thickens cards appear to shift a game from social deduction to logical deduction and tip the scales in the rebels favor. Without the plot cards, the game tends to lean towards the spies. I prefer the game without the plot cards. YMMV.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
When looking for games that play large numbers AND that play fast AND won't eliminate the players before the game is over, the options are rather limited.  This game solves that problem in spades.  Play is fast - perhaps even too fast - and no players will be eliminated from the game play until the very end.  Like its predecessor Werewolf, game play is dependent on the group dynamics.  Mechanically, the game works fine with pure strangers, but its potential emerges with group and player interaction history.  Suspicion, doubts, and double-crosses will drive the game to include the interaction and good confrontation it is suppose to have.  Without the banter, the game will play out and feel a bit like a group random outcome.  When personality comes in to play, the outcome is more questioned - for the benefit of all players.  This is a solid game that is well suited to filling a large group's attention for 30 minutes, but will likely need several plays by a group to really start to shine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A lot of hidden role games are complicated by having many roles each with their own special ability to keep track of. This makes it tough to bring these games out at a party where there are a lot of new players who can't pick up on the subtle interactions between different roles on their first playthrough.

The Resistance is essentially a minimal working model of the "hidden role" mechanism, so that everyone's able to participate effectively immediately after learning the rules.

RATING: 8
This game is best played as written, with the Plot cards. I get kind of disgusted when told people play with blind spies, or when people reject the plot cards. When played *ahem* properly, this game is the best hidden role and deduction game ever, with its elegance and social jockeying.

The new edition sacrifices one of this game's greatest strengths, portability, while also replacing its beautiful cover art with George Patsouras' kind of uncanny valley-ish art. I find his stuff decent on cards, but a little vacant for more prominent components like the box.

RATING: 8
Fun to play. GRANDMA IS THE SPY DONT LOOK AT ME!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is one of those games that I think everyone should try once. While it is a social deduction game like Werewolf, which I'm not too fond of, it does do two things very well. First, it has no player elimination and creates an engaging experience from the start to end. Secondly, it manages to appeal to all types of gamers through its innovative and deceptively meaningful voting system. For family/social gamers, there is a simple to understand game where players can accuse each other based on their intuition. But for heavier gamer, the voting system creates concrete information to make meaningful decisions. In other words, this game works with both a social mindset and a competitive mindset.

Personally speaking, I think Avalon is the better "version" of the Resistance. While it offers less content, the variants in Avalon seem to be more balanced/play-tested. Plus, the simple addition of Merlin/Assassin really adds to the experience without much complexity. That being said, I will gladly play any version of The Resistance. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As many people have said, it cuts off all the fat from Battlestar Galactica, while retaining the core ideas of cooperation amongst possible betrayal, and trying the deduce the identities of the traitors (or trying to evade deduction in case of the traitors). I find it easy to get into the flow of it, unlike Battlestar. Great social game with a good bit of strategy.

RATING: 7.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A clever deduction game. Players are either part of the resistance or spies, and through mission assignments and through voting try to deduce who is who. 5 rounds, the team that wins 3 times wins the game.
This version comes with an expansion. 15 conspiracy cards are added to the game enabling more strategy and potential bluffing.
Great fun in a small box. It's more challenging to play as the resistance than it is to play as a spy, at least not using the expansion cards.
Unfortunately you need a minimum of 5 players to play this game.

RATING: 6

It's almost impossible to choose teams without a spy, unless someone screws up. Boring.

RATING: 5
Ez a játék egy kicsit a hagyományos "gyilkosozásra" emlékeztet, de itt sokkal konkrétabb megnyilatkozások vannak, nem csak vitázgatás, és a játékmenet jól le van szabályozva (max 5 kör pl.)
Bár a szabály alapján jónak tűnt, elsőre csalódás volt:  kuszának éreztem. Szerencsére többet is játszottunk vele egymás után, a 3. parti végére már megbarátkoztunk vele. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A decent game of bluffing and sabotage. A certain number of players (depending on the total number) have to secretly sabotage three of the five missions that make up the game to win. Players discuss and agree who should go on each mission, and the spies can choose to help or hinder the mission as they see fit, as long as they are chosen to go on it. The game is deviously simple, to the extent that it boils down to your ability to bluff and how well you know the other players, rather than the game itself.

Fun, quick, but gets less and less satisfying the more you play with the same group of people.

RATING: 6.5
The Resistance is a Wherewolf variant with a better theme, that corrects the flaws of the original game: there is no player elimination, and the lenght of the game is definitely shorter.
The base game is quite straightforward, and every player has a clear objective, but there's lots of room for bluffing and deduction.
I am not the greatest fan of the genre, but this game is quite enjoyable and fun to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The Resistance is one of the first games that started the deluge of social deduction games, and to this day, it remains one of the best.

Some may argue that the game is too vanilla without the "plot twists" (no longer included in the latest edition of the game) and that it's essentially a "solved" game; however, this may only be true if you consistently play with the same group. Having played the game with 41 different people at this point, I can safely say that two of my plays have never been the same.

Some players are great at being the spies, while others can even fail before the game has begun. Therefore, some games can fail utterly with the Resistance having deduced the spies by the second round; however, with repeated plays, your group can really form memorable and comical experiences. A game that makes me laugh is a great game in my books.

I'm not a very good spy, personally. I tend to remain quite silent as a spy, while as a member of the resistance, I am fairly vocal. The fun of the game for me lies in puzzling out who the spies may be - I don't care too much about the bluffing and deceptive aspects of the game. Therefore, I have come to the conclusion that cooperative deduction games are more up my alley than social deduction games.

I have also played Avalon, the Arthurian legend spin-off of the Resistance, many times as well, but I think that I prefer the vanilla gameplay of The Resistance more.

Overall, every gamer should try The Resistance at some point. It is a classic that needs to be experienced.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played this game with 5 players and the basic version and as that goes I have to say this game is broken for that.  The spies won everytime easily.  Perhaps the game would be better with more players, but as far 5 players go it is unplayable.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Very interesting social deduction game. The theme is great and fits the game superbly. The game is very hard to win for the rebels as the spies seem to have the edge in the base game. But playing the game is reward enough without even winning. The discussions, accusations and paranoid statements that go around each round are hilarious. Very interested in the plot cards and how they change the game.

After a few more games it seems the plot cards are really necessary to give the rebels any chance of winning. And even with them it's still hard as hell. But the fun does not suffer from the difficulty to win as the rebels. Still a great game.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Components: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the game I was looking for when people tried to sell me on Werewolf. The concept is roughly the same, because the Resistance players have no genuine clues about the identity of the Spies, but here players aren't getting eliminated. I also like that you can use the voting to help deduce who might be working against the team. Then they add in those action cards which can give even more information, and I'm sold. It doesn't have quite the thematic thrill that I get from Shadow Hunters, but it's still fun. I like being on both sides of the game, and playing multiple games in one night is often more fun. Thankfully the game is also ridiculously short so you can play it as many times as you want in one session. Very fun game.

RATING: 8
An extreme game which can be very fun or very boring. Requires players to be comfortable with each other for the bantering to start.

Best with 7-8 players. Do not recommend playing with less than that.

Played with 3 different groups. Was very entertaining with a particular group; whereby several players try real hard to convince others of their innocence and also provided analysis.

Players who are not flexible in playing, and especially dislike to lie, or very quiet could really spoil the game. For example, if the spy's identity is obvious, he could redirect attention to himself and even implicate an innocent player down as a fellow spy.

The special cards distributed by the leader adds flavor and dynamics to the game, when compared to Avalon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pro's:

1) The base game without the special powers is actually a great introductory game for newbies.
2) The game really benefits from having different personality types at the table.

Con's:

1) The game gets stale really quickly and can develop a really mathy metagame that ruins the fun social dynamic at play. I recommend playing with the 7+ player mark to hopefully mitigate this.
2) Someone with a really dominant personality can pretty much derail the game entirely. 
3) There may be a time when the game totally flops.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A witch hunt game: suspect everyone so when the game’s over you can say «I knew you were the infiltrator». In the usual run, a couple of players (those who know more deeply the game) will do all of the thinking while the others just follow their suggestions while understanding almost nothing of what’s happening around them, even when it’s their turn.

It’s pretty boring for the casual gamer. (September 2011)

[b]Update[/b] - After further playing it I’ve come to enjoy this game: undoubtedly it’s all about the right group.

Fun and laughter-inclined people around the table can do wonders indeed and my all-new feeling towards The Resistance is the result of sharing it with a bunch of loud and cheerful people: none of them joined my previous bleached attempts at this game, which therefore used to turn out too cold, analytical and success-oriented to be somehow entertaining, whereas it should be light, carefree and noisy to the extreme, just like we’re playing it now.

Due to this good experience, in October 2014 I’ve decided to raise my rating from 3 to 9, which now I feel fits the game way better.

RATING: 5
I like the design goals, and the concept is a good one.  But three to five rounds is to me far too short to get any useful information at all *and* have time to put it to good use. I actually feel as though this game would be better if it were twice as long, so people can gradually form opinions based on observation and have an opportunity to use this info in a way that positively impacts the game.

Also, random annoyance: So one side is the Resistance, which is a group of saboteurs and spies fighting against some entity not appearing in the game. But the other side are Spies, a group of saboteurs and spies fighting against... the Resistance? So the Spies are basically a resistance against the Resistance, whom themselves you could call spies in a manner of speaking. So which is which again? Oh forget it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

sold

RATING: 5
This is a fun deduction/discussion game. The more people you can get to play the better. It's one of those games you could sit around the table, or just sit back on the couch. It's pretty straightforward to play an could probably be taught to most people.

The group I played with got tired of it after a few rounds because it's the same game each time. Once the group figured out each other's tells it was pretty easy for the Resistance side to win. I'm sure if we played again on a different night fun would have been had again =)

This game is super group dependent. I played a few times and had some laughs. Another time I played everyone just seemed bored. I suppose the same could be said about any social type game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a modern classic for a reason. I am a huge fan of Battlestar Galactica and the description of this game as "Pocket Battlestar" is apt. It carries some of the same, fun social misdirection games in a tight footprint of mechanics, rules and gameplay. The only criticism I could imagine for the game that it doesn't seem to have the kind of weight of having your success matter the way longer games like Battlestar do; it plays so quickly that it seems like you're playing about air; the deception is just for its own sake. That said, I can't imagine that anything else would be possible with a game lasting thirty minutes so that's not a fair criticism ultimately. Virtually every gamer should own this title. It fills a niche so perfectly that I can't imagine another title doing so in an improved fashion.

Edit: The Resistance: Avalon has essentially fired the original Resitance for me. Having the Merlin character just improves the game. It's still an 8, but Avalon is a 9.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Filler para grupos. Juego de deducción y faroleo. Hay dos bandos: los espias de la resistencia y los agentes del gobierno. En cada turno, un jugador propone un equipo para una misión (abstracta, no se realiza nada en la misión) y el resto de los jugadores vota para aprobar o no ese equipo. Cuando un equipo es aprobado, los jugadores del equipo juegan una carta que determinará si la misión tiene éxito. Uno tiene que deducir los votos de cada uno para averiguar quien es el espía y evitar que participe en misiones. Gana la resistencia si consigue que fallen tres misiones o el gobierno si consigue que tres misiones tengan éxito. Muy entretenido.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Totally made Werewolf obsolete.

No moderator. No player elimination. More interesting discussions. Unlike in Werewolf, there's actually a basis to accuse someone with.

And why play Battlestar Galactica for 3 hours when you can play this in 30 minutes for the same feel.

The enjoyment of the game and its rating is highly group dependent. If you have a group of quiet euro cube pushers who prefer multiplayer solitaire, then this game will be a dud.

I am of the minority that highly prefer this to Avalon.

The rating is a 9.5 when the group dynamics are there. Otherwise the rating is a dud if you don't have the right group mix.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.8
Player interaction is very important for me and this game has just about the highest player interaction I have experienced in any game and therefore earns a lot of credit in this regard. It is also fun and short to play, but ultimately, when you strip it down, it is just a lottery. If you are a good guy you virtually have no control over the game in your efforts to win. As others have pointed out, if the spies play it well they should win everytime and 5 turns is also to short to make any meaningful deductions. The more you try and convince people the worse it gets as there is nothing you can actually show or do to prove your allegiance if you are a good guy. This is very frustrating and the game descends into a paranoic shouting match. I will play again as a filler as it is fun and amusing and if nothing better to play.

RATING: 9
Social deduction game that involves lies as usual. This game shows how hard to beat the 'evil' one. Surely a party game due to its nature where the more the players are, the merrier this game will be. I have to admit, this game is quite imbalanced in terms of the winning chance. The spies would win much more often than the resistance side, I think it's because they knew each other beforehand. There's a very good alternative way of playing, in which even the spies do not know each other. Theme-wise, this alternative would be better because, on the field, intel agents even need to identify who is foe and friend by themselves, right? I still give high points for this game, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I dislike games like Werewolf to the extreme, and this is not far enough removed from such games to be much better.

Basically, The Resistance takes the whole secret role mechanic and puts a little meat on it in the way of structured voting.  Based on the results of various voting, players can deduce who the bad guys are, and thus keep them out of missions.  If enough missions succeed, the good guys win.  If not, the bad guys do.

It rates slightly better than Werewolf simply because it's over quickly, and there's at least some room for reasoning rather than blind guessing.  I see how people that are into this sort of thing enjoy it, but it's not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Spectacular game gets more fun every time.  Looking forward to a play with non-gamers.

RATING: 7
The quintessential social deduction game, and for good reasons. Players must figure out the traitors of the group before they can sabotage 3 out of 5 missions. Like most games of this genre, the overall experience can vary significantly from group to group based on how much players enjoy the game and how familiar they are with each other. Without the expansions and the extra roles, the difficulty may be influenced by the player count based on on how many people are on each team. A classic of the genre for a reason.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This feels like a gameier Werewolf which has, unfortunately, lost a little bit of its soul somewhere along the way. I'm not entirely sure why, but this never gets our usually raucous and suspicious group shouting and accusing. 

There's lots of room for bluff when you're a spy, and information for deduction when you're not, but I'm not sure I would characterize either as particularly "fun". There's something that just feels so dry and mathy about the whole experience.

Sidenote: The packed in expansion can be skipped. It just adds unnecessary chaos without much benefit.

Update: One Night Werewolf does everything I want from this game so much better. The added chaos of the roles and tension of the time limit make for a ton of laughs, accusations, and of course, panicked shouting. The only reason I keep this one around is it's about the only pure social deduction game that scales down to 5&6 well.

Update: Further lowing this to a four. I really just have no desire to play it ever. Too often does it drag out to excruciating 45+ minute games, and every game seems to follow the same script: first mission passes, regardless of number of spies in it > second mission: same people from the first mission +1 > if second mission failed, the +1 gets swapped for someone else, otherwise same people +1 > repeat. The effective elimination also bothers me - if you're outed as a spy early you just get to sit there the whole game. Blech.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
YOU ARE THE SPY! Almost always turns into bad logic and shouting with distractions from the spies. Great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Not my favorite.  It isn't that I can't bluff successfully, it's that oftentimes this game can devolve into a "loudest voice in the room wins" scenario.  When I bluff, I tend not to be loud about it.  That can be a problem.  It will be a problem for anyone who isn't aggressive about accusing everyone else of treachery.

If you're the spy and you can successfully derail the game, sending the other players off to be bogged down in a quagmire of paranoid accusations and counter-accusations, it can be fun.  But most of time, it really isn't all that fun for me, even when I am on the winning side.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I know this is probably a great game with the right group, but so far my various gaming groups consist of 3-4 players or so. When we are finally 7+ or so we tend to play other games, and the first time I played this (with some non-gamers included) it fell flat. I played it a couple of times half a year later with another group, and this time it was a lot more pleasant.

I have to say, though, that the gameplay itself isn't that great, what's fun about the game is the interaction and accusations etc.! It's quite tough to figure out who's who within the first couple of rounds, and as it's over after at most 5 rounds, the actual gameplay feels a little limited - it's extremely hard to actually deduce who is who, and this is a factor I don't like much. I would argue that decent spys in a 7p game will win almost all of the time unless they make some questionable decisions. With 3 spies it is often tough for the resistance as it's going to be hard not sending a spy on a mission - especially as the spies can play a success card on the first mission (like most people do), and then it really doesn't give much information. What DOES reveal a lot of information is the voting pattern!

On the other hand, this game honestly needs to be played with experienced players who understands the game mechanics well - and what to do in order to get information! I've played it with so many new players who simply just don't understand the huuuuge importance of rejecting a mission... And then they sit back and wonder why they lost as the resistance!

If you include the plot cards, the game becomes more open and more based on facts and less on accusations. 

I will keep trying to introduce it to other people as I like games with hidden roles and traitor mechanics!
So, my rating will probably go up and if I find the right crowd to play it with, I can definitely see it be more like an 8 than a 6. But for now it's a 6 as it's a very situational game - it can be great under the right circumstances and fall flat under other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is what Werewolf, Mafia and Bang! should have been. Lots of scope for bluffing, arguing (in a nice way) and making partially informed decisions. More importantly there is NO elimination. It works with 5-10 though 6-8 seems to be best. With 9 or 10 it becomes very difficult for the resistance to win and some people will be left out of the missions entirely which can become boring for them. Play around a circular table if possible so as to involve everyone equally and to be able to observe all the subtle clues (particularly with the commander & bodyguard variant).

BASIC GAME: rated '6'.

Variants:

ADVANCED GAME with the plot cards - Not so much fun as the cards provide perfect information (at least for some) though this does enable the resistance to win in a larger group. It's quite possible to be 'outed' as a spy in round one which makes for a boring game. Rated '5'.

THE COMMANDER (Dumbledore) & BODYGUARD (Morpheus) - With the right crowd I'd rate this an '8'.

The above with the 'DEEP COVER SPY'. This particular spy is not known to the commander. Fun, too.

RATING: 8
Wow, finally a great social interaction game that goes to 10p. This game is fun. I can see this being my go to game for large groups - and I am sure most people will have a great time playing. Highly recommended.

Update: I always take this game with me if I know there will be more than 5 players. You can teach it to anyone in about 3 minutes, and it takes about 10 minutes to play. Everybody has fun. The perfect filler for larger groups, and good enough to be the main course if needed.

Update 2: The deductive parts of the game become much less pronounced with more players - it turns into more guessing. It it still much more structured then werewolf, however, it turns into more of a social game then a deduction game.

RATING: 8
Pretty good hidden role game that relies a lot on who you play with and how good you are at lying. Plays in the right amount of time for what it is going for. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Fabulous bluffing game that degenerates into a squabble of accusations!  Love this even more with the max number of players.  A good party/intro game as well due to its simple mechanic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rated 9 after two back-to-back plays. What an absolute blast. This was advertised as a werewolf game with no elimination and that works with 6+ people. And, it delivers exactly as promised. Everyone pretty quickly got into the spirit of the game, and there was plenty of laughter.

Inexpensive, small box game that plays great up to 10 people and lasts less than 20 minutes? That's pretty much a no brainer for most collections.

Update: played this with some non-gamers... three straight games in a row. I'm shocked. This is a gateway game. We had an absolute blast. I still haven't played this with the expansion cards, and I anticipate those cards provide more information  that makes choices a bit more informed than simply reading people's poker faces. But the base game is very approachable for relatively inexperienced gamers. This is a wonderful game.

Update: tried this with 5 players. Ugh. This really is a 6+ player game.

Update: Played this with the expansion cards, and the extra information added really helps. When people are forced to vote first, or peek at mission card, or pass their loyalty card, it helps drive table talk, which is the heart of this game. Once people have played this once or twice, definitely give the expansion cards a shot.

Update: traded away, but only because I picked up The Resistance: Avalon. This is a great game, and frankly, people can choose the theme that suits them best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 9
Update on 1/6/12 a year or so since my first play and after a bunch of recent plays at the lab: All my comments below still apply, but i just keep enjoying it more and more after every play. Screw it! It's a 10. How could it not be given that I split my gut laughing EVERY SINGLE TIME. Admittedly, I wouldnt rate it as highly with a group of strangers. And the beer helps. But it is 100% smart fun.

Old comment from 1/11: A mini-surprise. I played back-to-back games of this us-versus-them deduction and bluffing game, playing on the 'spy' team both times. Now, I am terrible at bluffing and worse at deduction, so I really stunk up the joint. I'm pretty sure I helped bring down my team in the first game. The game was pretty wild and wooly - there were nine of us, of which three were spies, but in the end, it was a fun. Real fun. Not a pastime. Not interesting. No 'multiple paths to victory'. Just a hootin' time. It is likely that I enjoyed this because the company was good, the night was late, and the beer was plentiful. It usually wouldn't be a game I thought twice about. I'm glad I played.

Plays a big group? Check.
Plays even better with alcohol in the mix? Check.

It's also great when I have a group of 7-8 gamers over, we split into two groups for most of the night, but then want one game to bring us all together at the end of the night.

RATING: 8

One day I'll pick up the published version to play with friends.

RATING: 7
sf
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Deduction done right.  I love the meta-game.
I remember finding this game in the database and reading session reports for it and thinking it sounded like the coolest thing ever.  When I got to play, I was not disappointed.

There are interesting decisions (if played correctly) to be made by both the spies and the resistance.  The benefit of forcing multiple votes for missions can really ratchet up the tension for the spies, as they have to remember to keep their stories straight.  Throwing the other spy under the bus can be a dangerous and rewarding endeavor if done at the right time.

I could go on and on about what I love about the game.  Timing, trust building, backstabbing... its all in this little box just waiting for you and the right group of people.  The only thing that brings it down is that it does need the right group of players.  But if you have that group, you will have some games you will remember.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The Resistance was an early game that removed player elimination, allowing all players to be involved in the game until the end. However, the game still does take a while, and games like One Night Ultimate Werewolf and Two Rooms and a Boom offer a quicker experience.

RATING: 8
Really really good.
-1 because it has some player numbers where balance is a bit broken.

Compared to Avalon:
While it is good to have special roles included in Avalon leaving them out, especially Merlin, makes the game fairer. In Avalon as an evil one even if you are bad you have quite high chance to win just to pick someone randomly as Merlin. While it is fun I prefer this version over Avalon.
But this is such a minor difference both are great games.

Update from 9 to 8:
Avalon wins since you can play Resistance with it but it doens't work on the other way.

RATING: 7
I grew up with murder in the dark. Then, played some games of werewolf/mafia. When we discovered Resistance, our minds were blown. We played this game soo many times. This was a solid 8 for a long time, but over repeated plays I find that the arguments and discussions become pretty repetitive. These days Resistance has been replaced by Coup, Two Rooms and a Boom, and most especially Secret Hitler. I think SH took what Resistance started and improved upon it in virtually every way except the controversial theme (which unfortunately limits it's ability to get to the table in some situations).

RATING: 7
[u]Bluffing[/u] and deduction party game with great fun.
Homemade copy for 5 players using some [i]Coup[/i] cards, normal cards and poker chips:
- 2 Assassins (for spies) and 3 Contessa (for Res. team);
- Normal cards from a deck (5 red & 5 black) for all voting;
- Poker chips (1 Dealer Leader, 3 blue as guns, red/black for the board).

RATING: 7
A very simple werewolf like game that may lack a little balance - it seems to be heavily favouring the empire spies. But is very fun none the less for the bluffing, attempted puzzling logic and more bluffing. 

3:2
2 wins as Empire
1 Win as Resistance
2 Losses as Resistance

I think the game may actually play better if the spies do not know who each other are.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Excellent party game. Be prepared to have your loyalty called into question with regularity. Depending on your role, you must protect your identity and act in a way that does not give you up while allowing you to succeed in your objective. In any given game, you are on one side or the other, and you either want most missions to succeed or you want most missions to fail. Players with strong social deductions skills do well in this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
A good little game of group paranoia, this distills down the traitor element from Werewolf and Battlestar Galactica to its purest form.  Players first find out their role, then select each other for "missions" that could end up being successes or failures, based on cards played by the mission specialists.

REVISED RATING - After clarifying some key rules and adding in the plot cards, my opinion of the game improved greatly (6 to 7.5).  I see no reason not to use the plot cards, as it's easily understood, and creates more balance in the game, with some exciting twists.  This can really be a lot of fun, and I can see multiple plays per sitting to be normal.

RATING: 4
Fairly fun social deduction game. The basic rules don't really offer much opportunity for deduction, so, once the players have learned not to give themselves away as spies, accusations seem to be based on little more than random guesses and groupthink. Optional rules like the Plot Thickens cards or the Merlin role from the Avalon edition (which requires no extra components to use in the regular edition of Resistance) give players more information to work with, though, and make it more interesting.

RATING: 9
I love social deduction games and I love Coup Indie Games), so we thought we'd try this one out.  We, so far, have focused on the base game only.  I imagine, over time, we may want to explore expansions.  

It has a Mafia/Werewolf feel.  You do need to deceive and that can get intense, depending on the players.  But there's a twist.  You vote with cards anonymously.  There is a deduction element and voting element.

The good: no one is eliminated and the game goes pretty fast.  We played two games in 25 minutes.

RATING: 10
Excellent social game and one of the best.  I think i've played this game well over 100 times and it still never gets old.  I enjoy it at the lower player counts (5-7 players).  Works well as a party game, filler game, gateway game, and can even take over a game night.  Fast and addicting what's not to love. Playing in teams is always something fun and different. I think this game has to be one of my 10's.  It offers one of the most fun and unique experiences in tabletop gaming (no offense but Werewolf, Saboteur and all the other similar games have NOTHING on the elegance and greatness that is The Resistance).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Components: Not a great production design, making the common mistake (in my book) of trying to accomplish entirely with cards what should have been done with other media. 1) the leader should be a pawn; 2) the identity cards should be entirely unlike the other objects, so we don't accidentally reveal them (e.g. tokens); 3) the mission votes should be via colored beads into a little opaque sack (and the remaining bead could go into another little sack), so that they are pre-mixed prior to counting, and it's much easier to return the unused bead without showing it. Too many similar components for a game where only half the people have an incentive to be guarded with their actions; it's too easy for the honest person, who doesn't have anything to hide, to accidentally reveal that, in fact, they are with the resistance.

Experience: I like that there is no moderator, and that there is such a narrow time window for success for both teams. In my one playing, I made several errors that cost my spy team the game, which is a positive aspect to me, because it means that player decisions actually matter, and that there is strategy.

I dislike the resistance/spy theme, because they both imply subversiveness, and my group had trouble remembering which one was trying to undermine the other.

Last Played: 2012-09-29
Eagerness to Play Again: Within a year

Plays (1):
9 players: 1

RATING: 6
Fun game. We ran through it three times with seven people. We may have been playing it wrong, but there was some question as to whether or not the leader should change after each mission. The rules say that when a mission fails the leader passes clockwise. It doesn't say anything about the succession of a mission, though the inference is that if it succeeds then the leader would not change. However, depending on whether the leader is a spy or not, he pretty much controls it after the first successful mission because he just knows. Might be better with more people.

RATING: 8.3
This is an instant classic and took the social experience of One Night Ultimate Werewolf and turned it into an actual game.  The combination of hidden roles with social deduction and voting on who goes on the mission to score the round creates the experience of Werewolf but streamlines it and gives it order.
6-8 players is absolutely the sweet spot but if you have that size of a gathering you can allow anyone from a hardcore strategy gamer to someone who's never played a game in their life to have a blast.

RATING: 7
The original social deduction game, and definitely a classic.  The only reason it got cut for me is because it doesn't make a great first impression.  No one really figures out the optimal strategies and behavior, or when to vote for or against a team, until repeated plays.  And with my limited opportunities for 5+ player gaming, that rarely happens.

Likewise, the extra roles are cool, but they don't come out until everyone learns the basic game.  For me, that rarely happens.

So, while often dream of what this game could be (same for Dead of Winter) it just doesn't happen for me.  I need my large player games to be instantly grokkable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Expectations were high, but after 3 plays of The Resistance I'm impressed.

Compared to Werewolf:
- the deduction-game is more intense
- psychology is a bit different: no 'life-threatening' situations, but still a very paranoid experience
- players do not die - so most of the times the game stays interesting for all players.
- expansion cards add some nice twists. Smart spies can use the obvious disavantage of the cards to great effect.
- no neutral "story-telling" player needed, so everyone participates in the action.

So, if you are a fan of werewolf: try it! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The Resistance distills the best element of most hidden role games into its very core. The possibilities for deduction, paranoia and social interaction are almost endless. The only fault of The Resistance is that because of its pure focus on the traitor-aspect makes it a bit dry and devoid of theme (regardless of the backstory it has). Still, I would definitely recommend this game for anyone looking for a great social experience game, as it definitely shines in that area.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game is great for literally anyone.  My parents like it, my friends like it, my 11 year old cousin likes it.  Everyone should own this game.

RATING: 7
I've said everything I needed to say in my Secret Hitler review. I think The Resistance is a good game and it had it's time in the spotlight but for me personally it's been replaced by Secret Hitler.

I said it in the Secret Hitler review but I'll say it here too. The Resistance feels more like a logical deduction game dealing with facts and less of the social aspect of reading people. Secret Hitler deals with probabilities and uncertainties with waaaaay more human psychology and soical interactions. As a long time poker player I prefer the latter.

RATING: 9.5
This game is the best game I have ever played. It is a short (30 minute) game with an excellent traitor mechanic. Provided your group doesn't have an issue with lying, the game is loads of fun and different strategies are used for each game to throw off the resistance members.

The game is easy to learn and always a great laugh. It doesn't take long to play, so one game is always possible at the end of a gaming night. Furthermore, the game itself is exciting enough to play several times in a row, so it's easy to fill a few hours of gameplay with just the resistance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The Resistance is my go-to game to bring to gatherings/events where there will be a good-sized group of people who want to play a game. I love the tension this game brings, and people really get into the game quickly even if it's their first game. It's always fun to see everyone trying to figure out who the spies are, and watching everyone accusing each other from the moment the game takes off. One note of caution: in my experience, people who are more sensitive or don't like confrontation do not seem to enjoy the game as much. It can be frustrating for some players if they know they are not a spy and everyone is yelling at them calling them a spy. It's just part of the game, but it's just not some people's cup of tea.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
5-10

De leider kiest spelers voor een missie. Elke speler mag deze missie goed- of afkeuren. Bij een gelijk aantal stemmen gaat de missie niet door en wordt de volgende speler leider. Wanneer een missie 5 keer wordt afgewezen, scoren de spionnen een punt. 

Wanneer de missie doorgaat, maken de geselecteerde missieleden in het geheim hun keuze. Leden van The Resistance stemmen altijd positief. Spionnen mogen zowel positief als negatief stemmen. Als alle kaarten positief zijn: 1 punt voor the resistance. Als er minstens 1 kaart negatief is: 1 punt voor de spionnen. Wie als eerste 3 punten scoort, wint. 

Elke leider mag tijdens zijn beurt aan een speler naar keuze een plotkaart geven.

Plotkaart met leidersymbool: meteen uitspelen.
Plotkaart met cijfer 1: op een moment naar keuze uitspelen
Plotkaart met vierkant: blijven liggen tot het einde van het spel.

RATING: 9.2
Probably 9 or 10 months before writing this I tried to make my own version of the Resistance to see if I liked it before I bought it. It fell real flat with my wife's family, who was the primary group I played One Night Ultimate Werewolf with. It just didn't seem to have the intensity and excitement of ONUW. I had pretty much written off the game as a duller (but necessary) precursor to the great game that came to be ONUW.
That is until last week. I was at a local bargain store, and I found the Resistance on the shelf for $5. Being the board game enthusiast that I am, there was no way that I could pass up such a popular game for so cheap, even if I didn't really like it. I took it to a game night last Friday night, and boy was it fun. I'm not sure what we did wrong the first time, or if it's just that the real components provided for more discussion, but I finally understand the praise this game has gotten.

RATING: 8.6
[August 2017 - 8.6] 
Drops another few notches as Secret Hitler has mostly surpassed this one for me, albeit, The Resistance is a little cleaner on the rules, and the better intro game.

[December 2015 - 8.8]
It slips by a few notches. Still a great game, but there are some other quick games moving up my charts these days that I'm enjoying more. It can get a little stale in instances with the same players, but new players still absolutely love it!

[July 2014 - 9.0]
What can you say that hasn't been said before about this game? What makes it fantastic is introducing it to new players -- particularly a group where not everyone knows each other, or perhaps among co-workers, who never see this side of you. For those reasons, this game's simplicity and speed put it above others that are a bit more complex. Yes, if you just play with the same people all the time it starts to lose its appeal because everyone only has so many tricks up your sleeve. So find new players to play it with!

RATING: 10
If you have a group of smart, outgoing, talkative people this game is absolutely amazing. I've never felt so much tension, frustration, and pure excitement in a game. Perfect!

Edit: Nothing does what this game does. There is nothing in the world that could cause me to, after 30 min spent with total strangers, jump up and hug them like long lost friends, just because we won. You see, it wasn’t just ‘winning’, it’s the fact that we (the good team) were each alone, not knowing who to trust, and we read the group as best we could, and decided who to trust and who not to trust, and we were right!

Resistance is life in 30 minutes.

RATING: 7.5
This is a traitor game reduced to the basic essence of a traitor game - there are no other frills or chrome - just the traitor bit. But that is the intention and as such it works well enough to provide a fun filler experience on most outings.

Is subject to occassional 'breaks' - i.e. a lucky/unlucky first choice of mission team vitually throws the game one way or another. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love this game it's like Battlestar Galactica without the faff of having to shoot stuff it's the traitor mechanic gloves off anything goes all boiled down to it's raw pure form. My two favourite sessions of this were the first one where after being introduced as a new player with a load of others who had played this before I pretended to not quite understand the rules and asked to clarify how many spies there were after the shutting eyes phase. This made the others rule me out immediately after all how could I not know how many spies there were if I was one of them... muhaha, we (the spies) won that game easily. My other favourite session was where I was again selected as a spy, I spent a considerable amount of time working over a long suffering friend buttering him up and getting him in my pocket. At the start of the game he was a leader and picked me for his sole companion, we laughed and joked and the cards were revealed and the mission failed. I acted astonished and turned the tables on him saying that he was rigging the vote and making it look like I was the spy and that was fine just don't put me on any missions for the rest of the game. I did such a good job he decided that he must have made a mistake and ended the game prematurely which was logged as a technical win for the spies as I flipped my card over to reveal the spy. He trusted me more than his own brain and I have not let him live it down since. Brilliant stuff!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't think I can rate too much higher than a 6 because it is basically a "play the player" type game...which is not my favorite genre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Players are either loyal members of the Resistance, fighting missions against the Empire, or spies of the Empire, trying to sabotage the Resistance missions.  Simple card based voting game, where one player nominates a team of players to go out on a "mission".  A secret ballot is cast to see if the team is approved - if not, another team is proposed and voted on, etc.  Once the team is settled, those chosen secret vote the mission as successful or failed.  Three successful missions means players on the Resistance wins, otherwise three failed missions gives the win to the spies.  A vast improvement on Werewolf, where you always fear a random early exit - no player elimination, and a nice hunk of logic involved.  Very good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After a quick two games, this seems like a pretty cool game. Strange mix of bluffing, rational thinking, and straight up intuition (for better or for worse), it's a game I am NOT very good at (both games people were convinced I was the spy [they were right once]. both times it led to my team losing). Need to play this one more to get the hang of the politics of it all.

Edit (20AUG2011): So I have this game for a while, and I've got to say, it's pretty darn fun. The subterfuge of spy play is a bit nervewracking, but I admit it's great fun to somehow convince all the resistance members to put the mission into your hands, just to crush their hopes at a round 5 victory. Of course, it's even more satisfying to root out the spies and achieve rare but glorious victory over the evil power of your choice. Not for everyone, but overall a great game. Rating +1!

RATING: 7.5
Provided everyone gets into the game, this is awesome. Quick, easy to explain and excellent for large groups. To get everyone into the game, I make the current leader propose a mission for the group: IE: "I'm leading a mission and I need Patrick and Diana's help; we're going parachute into the library and steal all the books in the Twilight series..."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
a fast-playing werewolf variant I'd like to try again soon
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Have the retail copy now.  I've played the playtesting copy before and the Plot cards really add to the game by providing several more layers of information.  1) Who the leader is giving the good/bad cards to 2) Who the people with the cards choose to use it on and 3) The actual effects of the cards themselves

If BSG and Werewolf had a baby, it would be this game.

1) Like BSG and Werewolf, it has hidden good guys and bad guy roles
2) Like Werewolf, it's more of a party game (5-10 players)
3) Like Werewolf, it's pretty simple and does not require a lot of explaining to new players
4) Like Werewolf, it doesn't take 3 hours
5) Like Werewolf, there's an open voting phase, but instead of choosing who to kill, it's whether the chosen people get to go on the mission
6) Like BSG, It has hidden "skill checks" (missions) where the bad guys can choose to support or sabotage
7) Like BSG, there is no player elimination
8) Like BSG, there are ways you can look at someone's loyalty card or assign them special roles (with the Plot cards in the retail copy)

RATING: 5.5
got it mostly for my group rather than for myself -- game is fun, but is really hurt by lack of incentive for the resistance to do anything other than succeed. secret hitler has a much more interesting take on the idea, with the fascist policy track being a sort of push your luck mechanic. doesn't mean resistance is bad, but i'd prefer more depth and that mechanic would add a lot. however, resistance works as a more portable, easier to learn, and quicker version of SH

RATING: 8
For me, this is 90% of the fun of Battlestar Galactica in 10% of the time.  I'll take that deal!

My favorite thing about the new edition is that some of the cards are replaced with tokens.  The original edition had too many types of cards floating around!  I do miss the original's very small box, but the larger boards are nice to have.

UPDATE Jan 2013:
I think this game is the pinnacle of the "traitor" genre.  It cuts out all the crap and just delivers the fun in a tight little package.

RATING: 8
A spy-themed, quick-paced social deduction game.

A favorite for large gatherings- the more players, the better. Certain numbers of players can favor one side over the other, but the game is so quick that it usually leads to numerous plays in one sitting, with most players having a chance to play on each side at least once. Even better with the "Plot Thickens" cards.

RATING: 5
Overall, I have never seen the resistance win against the Corporation unless the Corporation makes a mistake during the game.

I enjoy the game but never expect to win since I rarely get to be the Corporation.

Update: I've now seen the corporation win a few times.  However, I am extremely bad at this game.  When I am the resistance I simply cannot figure out who is the corporation and especially when the corporation I can't keep a straight face which ultimately leads to me being found and I am effectively out of the game at that point.  

I don't mind hidden role games but I prefer ones that have additional effects once I am "found out".  Ones where my objective or at least actions change when I am revealed as a traitor instead of basically ruling me out of the game.

RATING: 7.5
I rate and consider both Resistance and the Avalon version as if they were one in the same - I always play Resistance with Merlin/Assassin (barring brand new groups) and I never play Avalon with anything more than Merlin/Assassin (I don't have any group who's interested in exploring these other routes.)

Resistance is a fine social-deduction game, and I'm sure you've heard of it if you're on this site. There's tension, betrayal and confusion - everything you need for a blast. While I'd still rank it above many of the social-deduction games that have come out since, the game has worn on me (I would have rating it an 8 or higher back in its heyday.)

I would always take a game of Deception over Resistance.

RATING: N/A
●Introduced and owned by a friend (thanks!!).
●Played my 1st werewolf styled game last night. I have to say that it was a hit with the meet up, with about 10+ count of plays.
●Rule is simple, and what else to admire other than the mechanics. Components wise, they're simple yet work, artworks are nice, and the game are based on card. Most important, with all mixed in the bowl, surprisingly, the theme is there.
●We played numerous rounds that night with the same group (new players added through the night), and I have to say that we were not sick of it, although I believe at one point, we will get bored if played with the same group. It's just that, the amount of plays you need to get to achieve that level of boredom is pretty high.
●It's not an urgent must have, but will get it if the price is right (not on sale in the country yet at the time of writing), and with it being a party game, the chance to have it is on the high side.
It was sweet and fun.

RATING: 9
First: You need to play with friends that are likely to participate actively, because the resistance is a game that requires creating an environment, and the game itself doesn't have it. 
It's a game for a big group of friends, you need to try connecting with the others to gain confidence or attract their attention, all depends on your role as an ally or a spy. 

A lot of fun, a lot of cheats. A big party game in a small box.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.07
Some say this is substitution for Mafia/Werewolf and they might be right, but for me Mafia is irreplaceable. However, when there are less than 10 people and more than 5, with mixed knowledge and feelings about board games, it could be the very pocket in which the Resistance shines.
It is straight, fast and fun, cool with variants even cooler without them. There is no player elimination which is a big plus in comparison to Mafia, and there is no moderator for eyes are closed only at the beginning of each game (or not at all if playing the blind spies variant), so it is more fluid and less loud. Which is not necessarily an advantage.
Hostile indent and hidden agenda expansions turn this game to Mafia without player elimination and moderator. Well they turn it to Avalon literally, so it's a win.

[b]Edit:[/b] Upgraded from 7 to 9 with Hidden Agenda module.
[b]Edit:[/b] Dropped from 9 to 8.2 after 30 plays due to exhaustion.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] After the expansion the Commander/Merlin role improved the game drastically. One person knows who the bad guys are but must remain unapparent because if the bad guys detect him/her they will win the game no matter what.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Having played both this and werewolf dozens of times now, i've decided i prefer werewolf.

This game is more intense, especially in my group. Its got to the stage where its pretty argumental and although i win often enough, not that satisfying. 

Player order is pretty key here. There is no player order in werewolf.

You pass the leadership card around in one direction, so it often makes sense to take risks on players who are a long way from getting to be team leader again. This and other deductions are standard practice in my group and breaking them leads to immediately being labeled spy. 

If the spies are last in turn order (unlikely but it does happen) then they have a real uphill struggle as the resistance can with a bit of luck win the game with out them ever getting a say in it.

The expansion cards up the conflict and argument in the game even more. The can force players to show their hidden cards to another player whilst everyone else is watching. This can lead to some very heated arguments over who is a spy and who is lying. If you like this, you will love this game. Personally i don't mind it as long as it remains light hearted. In Werewolf the greater ambiguity keeps it light, here intensity reigns.

RATING: 8
So why did I bump this from 5 to 8?
Because someone told me:
"If you in the first round vote YES on a mission you are not on, it implies that you are a spy. Having no information on people, would make it a bad situation to send to strangers, when the could send you.
However. If you ARE a spy, you KNOW if one of the to on the mission is a spy, and might therefor vote YES."

We played it at Essen2014 - and it was a blast. Shouting and accusing each other, trying the strangest deductions; I think the rest of the game room hated us.

They should have been envying us.

Love the game. Probably with the right crowd.

RATING: 7
Love this game. Probably better with groups of no more than 7 people (at least in my experience) or it seems that the spies have too much of an upper hand. Also, you need to play it with the right people. Some people don't get the game or just don't see the fun in it because they focus on the mechanics, while, of course, most of the fun here resides on the interaction, the bluffing, the joking, the trash talk and the deceiving. I would play this game every time someone asked me to. Would like to try the Avalon version or at least integrate the Assassin and Merlin in this version somehow.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I consider The Resistance to be a condensed version of BSG.  By looking at it this way I am surely setting myself up for a downfall as I consider BSG to be my favorite game.  If you like BSG but find it to be too long and fiddly, then this or Shadow Hunters is probably the game for you.  I should probably compare The Resistance to Werewolves as they have a similar weight.  Well, this one has no player elimination which is a good thing.  Regarding player numbers, The Resistance plays from 5 - 10 people whereas Werewolves I only consider to be good when you have 10+ people, therefore neither game makes the other obsolete.  The only thing I can say is that right now I have only played this game with 5 players which I don't think would be optimal number and without any of the Plots which I think would make the game more interesting.  So I rate the game a tentative 6 and I can only see it's score increasing with further plays.

RATING: 9
My first and stil favourite hidden role game. While now I enjoy a few tweaks, house rules, modules, etc, even the base game creates great tension and amazing stories. 
I remember when I first saw this on Tabletop (before playing), I was excited by the possibilities and how much fun it looked - and it has not disappointed.
Best moments: 
- Gus losing it for Graham and me in Bruges, with much (good natured) abuse
- 'Deep cover' Cawley announcing his role too early
- Playing whole listening to the interstellar soundtrack.

RATING: 6

RATING: 10

The prob is partly addressed by the expansion, but that adds complexity which is not always ideal for newcomers.  If you love lying to your friends and family or accusing them of being a treacherous ne'er-do-well, this game is for you!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[2 plays]  I looked forward to playing this game, but it fell a bit flat.  One possible reason is that I played with a group of people who were mostly also new to the game.  From what I've heard about this, it sounds like the subtleties of the game really emerge as you gain more experience with it.  

My first game could be a useful lesson in what to avoid in a first game: the randomly-chosen start player, deciding who to send on a mission, randomly decided to go with the next players to his left.  This resulted in the development of a small bloc of players early in the seating order who trusted each other, and kept choosing each other for missions.  It also resulted in half the people on the other side of the table feeling bored, unengaged, and fundamentally irrelevant to the game.  

I enjoy Werewolf in moderate doses, and this was supposed to be like Werewolf, only better.  It was also supposed to be a deduction game, and I love deduction games.  Instead of an awesome game that I'd really like, what I found in the Resistance--which is also of value--was a lesson about some things I really do and don't like in games.  

First of all, the Resistance really seems to me to be in the category of games where the game provides a structure to hang stuff on, but the bulk of the substance of the experience is brought by the players--or not.  Such games can shine under the right circumstances, but they are really vulnerable to fizzling with players who don't like them, or just don't get them.

Secondly, I love hardcore games of actual pure deduction, like Sleuth.  Games where there is something to be figured out, and the players are competing with each other to figure it out.  I don't so much care for games where what the players are trying to figure out is each other.  This is a game with a huge psychological element, where your deductions and observations and theories are all about the behavior and motivations of the other players.  Even in regular nondeductive boardgaming, I'm more of the "play the game, not the players" school of thought, as opposed to the other end of the spectrum with those who feel that every game is really about the metagame of playing the players.  

So the Resistance, though it may be great for those who like that sort of thing, is just not my cup of tea.  And I think I'll remember, next time a game like this comes along, not to get my hopes up.

RATING: 8.67
Ever played werewolf, and thought "Man, this would be a great game if only..."?

No elimination, no game master, no randomness, no need to be 20 for it to be interesting. Great game for people that would never touch a boardgame. Assured laughs and "WTF!?" moments when the bad guys reveal themselves at the end of the game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b][thread=644607]The PLAYMOBIL® Legion reviews "The Resistance"[/thread][/b]

(As of [b]21[/b] plays) A fantastic hidden-role alternative to [GAMEID=925], evoking similar levels of tension, suspicion and paranoia. The secret plans mechanic gives people more information to work with, but it is still predominantly a thrilling psychological exercise. I prefer this to pure Werewolf, in part because there is something [i]relatively[/i] tangible to work with from the start and there is no player elimination. The only thing that keeps it from being a "10" for me is that I get extremely tense when I play, and can only manage one or two games in a row before feeling totally burned out.

[b]Why this is in my Top Ten:[/b] This is, as far as I'm concerned, the ultimate hidden roles/traitor game. The basic premise is so simple and elegant, but the logic, intuition and persuasion required to play it well is phenomenal. Not everyone will like or "get" this game, and I will probably never attempt to play it with my family, but a well-played game of Resistance is absolutely unparallelled in the levels of tension and suspense that it generates. 

[b]2 year verdict:[/b] Still my favorite hidden roles/traitor game ever. I prefer the plain vanilla version, without plot cards complicating its inherent elegance.

RATING: 9
Superb social game, similar to Werewolf but arguably better (no player elimination, more info to use for deduction, and caters for smaller groups).  If you enjoy games with hidden roles, this is essential.   

Can introduce to [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/5929544#5929544]non-gamers[/url], but the Plot cards are essential for games with 7-10 players so it can be harder to teach larger groups of newbies.  Don't miss correcting the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/5602071#5602071]misprint[/url] in the first edition rules about the number of Plot cards to use.

See my pictorial review: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/592935

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The cliche fits: It's "Battlestar Galactica Lite." Its distillation allows you to kill an entire evening, but once the game starts to get "gamed," or mathed-out, it fails to be entertaining, only antagonizing. A worthwhile addition to a new collection, but plenty of other deception-style games have more meat with, albeit, more play time. The short games lend themselves to The Resistance's strengths, but the games become just a tad too long to be worth the trouble. For a shorter game, try Coup, which demands a spot in everyone's collection. For longer, try Battlestar Galactica or Dead of Winter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first experience with Res was a 6 player game that was dull. when I explained that everything you say and do gives out some information, the entire group just clammed up and said NOTHING... we pretty much played the entire game in silence for 30 mins and the spies won 3-1.
So I gave it a 4/10 and left it on the shelf for about a year.
My new group then wanted to give it a try, and we have 4 games back to back with acusation, counter points, banter, joking, more accusations, more double guessing and so on. 4 AWESOME games... 8/10 now, but you have to have a group that GETS the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Brilliant. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is a riot (apologies for the thematic pun).  As someone whose always enjoyed the "who's the traitor" style of games, especially the far more elaborate Battlestar Galactic, The Resistance fits a niche for me in terms of a short, fast-paced, and accessible traitor themed party game I have been sorely lacking since I used to play Mafia/Werewolf back in my childhood.  While the game seems highly biased towards the spies, I'd be hard pressed to say I never had fun as the losing team.  Additionally, if you are playing with a particularly engaged and creative group of people, dynamically creating a story to each mission, connecting it over time into an overall arch, is incredibly fun, especially if your team's rebellion takes a turn into the absurd.

My only real complaint is that the game cannot be played with four players, as getting five or more can be a bit difficult at times, even with this game's short length.  Otherwise I give it my fullest recommendation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
TH-2011

BGG awards

A party game of deduction and bluffing that reminds me of Werewolf but shorter & with more structure.  

Played with 6 & 7 people, all 3 variations (basic, blind spies, & the "expansion"--which is included with the game.  

This really demands the right crowd.  There has to be a  deceitful atmosphere with lots bantering and communication.  Instead it was just unenthusiastic accusations here & there such as, "oh, so he's the spy."  

We all thought the game was lacking and everyone agreed the mood had to be right.  We couldn't decide which of the variations we liked the least.

For these 3 games it was a flop.

7/19/11  Resistance: I had to basically reveal I was a spy. It's kind of disturbing how easily my friends bought into the "I'm stupid" defense.
