RATING: 4
Pro
-Game with traitor element
-Requires logic and deduction to win
-Scales with number of players
-Fairly short game

Con
-Requires the right group
-Weaker than Avalon (the only clues come from semi-boring events and how people react to those as opposed to inherent player abilities)
-Plot cards are uninspired...e.g. someone has to show their approve or disapprove of a group first...who cares?

RATING: 7.5
This is THE perfect deduction game.

PROS:
Bluffing, deduction, lying, back stabbing, paranoia.
Quick to play, easy to teach.
Cheap to purchase and doesn't take up a lot of table space. 

CONS:
The main issue is if a card gets scuffed or bent even slightly, people pick up on it easily and can quickly ruin the game. Not a big deal if you take care of them, but the same cannot be said about your fellow players.

RATING: 8
With the right group, this is a very fun game.  The fear and paranoia you feel when on the resistance and stone-cold lying and scheming required when you're a spy is so much fun.  Anyone that rates this game lower than a "9" is probably not playing with the right people or may themselves not be predisposed to a game like this.

Update: I'm lowering this game to an "8".  I still enjoy this game very much, but have found the game degrades to a screaming match when played with the same group over and over.  However, the game immediately rejuvenates when you bring in new players.

RATING: N/A
Sarah's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A Werewolf-like game that isn't anything like Werewolf.

Instead of random accusations and entirely made-up discussions the card play in The Resistance actually provides a solid basis for selective paranoia. Instead of "I think my neighbour was breathing harder tonight" you get "The mission with just John and Alexa was a success, but we failed when we added Michael to the team so he must be a traitor." It is, of course, still rarely that clear-cut.

That there is no player elimination and the game is shorter than its source of inspiration is the icing on the cake.

RATING: 9
Another game of hidden roles and elucidating which team a player is working for. Identified characters are not eliminated from play. Very fun, needs much more play to get to know it better. In some ways more complicated than werewolf, but in others, it is easier to work through the logic. Werewolf requires an extremely quick mind to be most effective. Resistance has less roles and is more spaced out timewise, so you can bide time and sabotage at a later time.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is one of the best Party games! If you have a voracious, spontaneous group you're gonna shout yourself hoarse.

Think of it as Battlestar Galactica without the many micro-decisions. It's distrust at its most quint-essential level.

Unfortunately its strength is also its greatest weakness. Players only ever participate in the same way, namely votes and missions. Where Battlestar has a myriad of ways players can get involved, Resistance fairly limits players. It makes the game really accessible to get into and fun, but after so many rounds, I do feel repetition creeping in.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b][i]The Resistance[/i][/b] is a fun quick lie-to-your friends social deduction game. Everyone goes through the game claiming to be a good guy while a few are actually bad guys lying through their teeth. People vote on a subset of the group to send on a mission and, if sent, bad people will sometimes cause the mission to fail while claiming that they would never have failed that mission. Games sometimes come down to shouting matches, but in a good way. It's the only game where I feel comfortable sitting down with 9 complete strangers and telling one of them (while smiling to remind that it is, after all, only a game) that I think they're a dastardly no-good liar, an evil servant of a totalitarian regime bent on sowing the destruction of all that is good and virtuous. They of course accuse me in kind (probably correctly) and by the end you've hopefully made some new friends.

Because comparisons to Mafia/Werewolf (another lie-to-your friends social game) are nearly inevitable, I'll add that I think The Resistance is superior in every possible way.

[b]Avalon vs Standard:[/b] I think The Resistance: Avalon is better than The Resistance. They both have the same core rules, but Avalon has alternate identities instead of once-a-turn action cards. The one thing I prefer in The Resistance is the dystopian future theme. Still, you cannot go wrong with either.

◊s◊

If you like it, I'd recommend graduating to something a little meatier quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Once your group has discovered every elemental trick to spot the spies (voting pattern, off aproving, etc), this degenerates in just "reading" people, which is exactly what I don't like in this game. Plus it is nearly impossible to win as resistant if a dumbass, stubborn or illogical player happens to be in your team, while you always have a chance even if a dumbass is a spy in your team. That's why I largely prefer Werewolf; I don't mind player elimination in exchange for a more entertaining experience.
This game requires heavy lecturing on tactics for novice players before playing, besides explaining the rules. And in my experience, it's incredible how stupid some people can be, not understanding why a mission approved by everyone in the table is a mission that's gonna fail, and so on. Not worth the pain sometimes.
Besides, plot cards are a must for the full experience, and at the same time may break the game, so... Not totally sold on this when there are alternatives; I will play it if we are just 7 and in the mood for secret identities.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The Resistance is very clearly inspired by the party/parlor game Werewolf. I don't like Werewolf. At all. In fact, I hate Werewolf with a burning passion. It seems completely pointless to me, because unless the werewolves have miserable poker faces, there really is no information upon which to base your lynching decisions. So the game invariably devolves into a drawn out session of oration and pleading and unprovoked low-level roleplaying.

The Resistance is probably about as good as a game of this genre can be. It has the psychology and bluffing that Werewolf fans will want, along with actual strategy, deduction, finesse, timing, tension, and other desirable game qualities that are so notably missing from Werewolf. The Resistance is still not a game that I would personally request, but I'm happy and willing to play it. And that should be considered a high compliment coming from someone who so utterly detests Werewolf. I may even pick up a copy. It's cheap, and I can foresee circumstances when it would be a nice game to have available.

The consensus seems to be that The Resistance plays best in the 7-10 player range (especially 7).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So much fun until you get a headache from trying to figure out who is who, who is lying, and who just doesn't know how to play this game very well.
The Resistance is a party game that presents a puzzle to be solved. Who among you are the spies that will ultimately sabotage your efforts to bring down the world-dominating super corporation? It's great fun, and you will be amazed how convincing your supposed best buddy is as he lies to your face about being a nasty, dirty, boot-licking spy. You almost wish they had included a real gun instead of a cardboard tile, because after the game is over and you realize he was lying to you all along, you will want to shoot him in the face.
I love hidden identity games. Werewolf, Mafia, Masquerade - all are great fun, and dependent upon the crowd you're playing with. But the puzzle behind The Resistance becomes frustrating because it's not a puzzle you can solve. After several plays, you begin to realize it's an exercise in frustration, and you will get frustrated. There are cards to introduce that will help one side have an advantage over the other, but those cards demonstrate how broken the puzzle is in the first place. 
I still love it, and it's a great way to get people interested in these types of games, but if you're going to introduce new players to it, sit yourself out and just facilitate the game until they get it. Then sit back and watch the sparks fly.
Oh, and make sure no one has a loaded weapon.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really love this as a hidden role game.

RATING: 9
Just great, unless you hate bluffing. A much tighter version of Werewolf, playable by as few as five. Very simple to play (you can get by without using several of the already few components), but with great depth provided by the player interaction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Our group's favourite Mafia variant, partly because it allows us to play with less than nine people, but mostly because it provides all the intense loyalty mechanics without any of the elimination. Easily learned, always engaging, and surprisingly well-balanced. The only issue we have ever had was with the rule for round 4 which states that the Spies need to insert two mission fails instead of one. This is supposedly supposed to make games easier for the Terrorists, and thus more balanced, but we have a win-rate of nearly 50% for either team -without- using the rule, so we usually remove it. New players who are familiar with Mafia will often question this choice if anybody is silly enough to actually bring it up, and it has consistently been the only mechanics disagreement to trip us up in this game.


We also have a lot of fun with descriptors, since the "Good Guys" are "Terrorists".

RATING: 9
Holy crap, this game has made for some EPIC game nights. When we are looking for a party game with larger groups I always reach for this.  Gamers and non gamers alike seem to love this game, and if you enter alcohol into the equation the game gets even crazier. The game scales very well from 5-9 players.  

Note: We played a "Silent" game a few weeks back which was amazing.  Basically no one can speak, only gesture and vote.  This forces you to rely on reading physical signs only.  You would be surprised how quickly you figure out who the spies are when mis-information isn't flying around. I highly recommend trying this as an alt house rule. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

Only issues I have is that you need at least 5 people. But I and my friend found that 9 people, that is the sweet spot. However, such a large group is quite often a problem to find (a group that has good chemistry). And even a total of 7 people might be difficult to find (which I recommend as the lowest number of players).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. It's different every game. The mind games that the spies play on the resistance are the main part of this game. It really gets your adrenaline pumping when you're down to the last mission, and you're sure of everyone but two. One is a spy and the other a resistance member, but you don't know which is which, and making the wrong choice can cost you the game. It's very intense, especially with more people. I recommend this game to anyone. The only downside, is that it requires at least 5 people, and some groups may not have that people available to play with. Other than that, 10 out of 10.

RATING: 9
With the Hostile Intent expansion, this is better than Avalon (as well as equipping you with all the Avalaon roles).

For most of the game, your only mechanical choices are "Yes/No". From that, it builds an outstandingly complex social game, providing just enough mechanical prompts and information to make the game work, and then getting out of the way and letting the social side take over. Amazing. One of the most important recent designs.

RATING: 7
This is a simple game of deceit. The instructions are straightforward and players are able to grasp the concepts of the game within minutes.

While the spies win a majority of the time, the game is always entertaining. It's funny to hear people's theories on the spy agenda, only to have them disproved at the end of the game. It's even more entertaining when that theory is correct and the spies somehow manipulate it to suit their purposes.

The game boils down to logic, but often times it turns into a screaming match when the spies circumvent any intelligent discussion with allegations of their own. This, however, never seems detract from the fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I prefer the avalon character game play over the resistance plot cards. We play this game quite often and its always fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is easily "best in class" for hidden role games.

The interactions are every bit as good as Werewolf, but has the added benefit that no moderator is needed, and there is no elimination ([i]anyone else hate getting killed on the first night?[/i]).  Also, there is more public [i]partial[/i] information in this game, resulting in involving more people in deductive logic.  Fantastic game for a group -- definitely a favorite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One game, we figured out who the traitors were in the second round, then proceeded to force a win.  The special ability cards and simplified system just aren't designed for veteran BSG players who know how to read actions.  Overall I don't think it is a bad game, and I would play again if asked.  It just isn't something I'm interested in buying, because there isn't a lot of meat on the bones.  I want to play again to see if maybe there is something I missed.

RATING: 9
I love this game. I love social deduction games, and this is ideal. It doesn't take too long, and feels very fluid. Streamlined and simple but the way the game progresses is going to bring different interesting decisions for each player depending on perspective. This is one of the most natural genres for me to fit into as persuasion is key as is the ability to set yourself quickly to the fresh logic of the situation. You'll get caught out if you set yourself to one way of thinking or playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is an excellent game with all the fun of Mafia/Werewolf in a much shorter timeframe. Playing this game made me remove Ultimate Werewolf from my wishlist. There's just no need to ever play it again when this game exists. It's not simply that it is more streamlined either though, it creates opportunities for bluffs and the like that I haven't seen in any other game of this type. The Plot Cards are where this game really shines, creating opportunities for the losing team to still pull out a win right to the bitter end.

RATING: 5

RATING: 4

RATING: 6
It's a reasonably good party/social game like Werewolf. I'm terrible at this kind of thing though. For some reason people never trust me, and I'm often not eloquent enough to state a reasonable case for myself. Opponents also tend to paint my mistakes as deliberate trouble-making. Meanwhile the guy silently brooding in the corner gets away with murder. Guess I should just learn to keep my trap shut. Anyway, this has the bonus of being much shorter than Werewolf, about 20 minutes per game. I'd be willing to play it every once in a while, but I found I liked the less free-form Castle of the Devil more.

RATING: 7.5
Playing with a young friend's copy (a Christmas gift to him last year), we had (3) enjoyable rounds of The Resistance (w/5 players), the streamlined Mafia/Werewolf game which takes the contest to a quick and tasty focus.

Playing a character is more than half the fun here, and the mind games is where the game is- the logic, the people-reading, the play and the bluster.

One loss (as a loyal Resister), followed by two wins, one loyal, and one as a spy.

A nice, fairly quick, involving game, with lots of play value. An excellent little game that easily lived up to it's reputation.

Un excelente juego de roles ocultos, deducción y engaño. Fácil de explicar y de jugar. Los tableros que se usan están diseñados acorde al número de jugadores, ésto está genial porque el tablero tiene toda la información necesaria y no es necesario buscar en las instrucciones ¿cuántos espías serán? o ¿cuántos jugadores van a cada misión?

RATING: 8
"The new guy—check him for 'spy-face'."

PS.  [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/800494/do-the-red-symbols-on-the-mission-cards-mean-anyth]The only way to play.[/url]

Also:

[q="HiveGod"]The [i]actual[/i] ending of that 10-player game came back to me, startling me awake like a suppressed memory; it wasn't a getaway van packed with explosives (though that's how most of them end), but rather "The Enhanced Interrogation of Rudy Tickmanfan, Suspected Spy":

Team Leader:  "Can we get him into the chair?"

[flops a success card]

TL:  "We do!  He's strapped in all cozy-like."

Me:  "Check his molars for nanotech!"

TL:  "Alright, we pull out the first molar—"

[everyone winces, expecting a flesh-effacing black cloud to boil out of Rudy's head]

[flops success card]

TL:  "No nanotech!"

Me:  "Check another one!"

TL:  "We pull some more teeth—"

[flops success card]

TL:  "It looks like he's clean!  But is he a spy?  Nope, he's not a spy after all—"

Me:  "Sorry 'bout the teeth thing, Rudy."

Rudy:  "S'okay."

TL:  [flops fail card]  "—[i]and then I shoot all of you[/i]."[/q]
(In the camping bin.)

RATING: 4
Over time I have grown to dislike Resistance. I need more actual "game" in my game, whereas this usually degenerates into a big argument/discussion.

Edit: Dec2016 - Put more succinctly, the game does not offer the players enough information to "solve" the puzzle. Therefore, the last couple rounds end up with everybody shouting at one another with no real way to actually figure out who the spies are unless players are terrible liars.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Didn't like this one. You have nothing to do on your turn other than argue, and there's very little thematic immersion to 'get into character'. Unlike BSG where you have a definite role, abilities, and several different things to do, this one lets you just pick people for a vote and vote twice. It's not interesting. It's also very scripted if you're not into this kind of negotiation game because you end up with no choices or decisions to make, because groupthink has already said 'if you do this, then you're that' so you have to basically either do it or not if you're not inclined to stand up and argue your position. Very dull. I'm not a natural liar, and without a good RP sheen like BSG, this feels much too direct for me. There might as well not be a game in there at all. Now, I admit, if you're into negotiation and enjoy flat out argument and deception, then you're away. For me, BSG scratches those itches in a much more interesting format with a much richer experience built around it. I'm also happy with Shadow Hunters doing something similar, because again there are things you can do and a variety of situations. This is a very tedious game system, and quite honestly you could play it with scraps of paper - you don't need to buy anything to play it. The group likes it, though.

RATING: 8.5
A brilliant deduction game for gamers and non-gamers alike, playing up to 10 people!  Pull it out at any party.  

Something worth considering: I used to think it was pretty much the perfect filler with larger groups, until a friend of mine expressed his dislike.  I asked why, and he claimed that it reminded him of being "the last one picked for football" because of the way it encourages players to be loud and argumentative, and even to pick on one another.  I hadn't considered this and it seems to be a very fair point.  I even have another friend who will simply refuse to play any game which requires "negotiation".

Still, I love it.

RATING: 7

+Great group game with fun tension
+Perfect playtime length
-Can be broken by meta-gaming
-Some players can feel left out

RATING: 5
I'm a fan of hidden identity games but this is too plain. It's more like a simple logic puzzle than a game. Always just boils down to "you're the spy" vs "no you're the spy" arguments. The problem is there is nothing concrete to go on like there is in better games like BSG so it ends up being totally random unless someone makes a mistake.

It's barely even a game, and certainly not "BSG lite" since there is no context to all the accusations and it's too much of a guessing game. "Werewolf lite" would be much more accurate.

In fairness, it's better with some different roles, and Avalon is a huge improvement.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
"ARE YOU A SPY!" Which is the the most common phrase uttered during this game.

Great little party game that always gets people laughing. There are two teams: The Resistance (blue) and the Spies (red). These factions are dealt out at random to the players. Once everyone knows who they are, everyone closes their eyes and only the spies open their eyes to see who is on their team. There are five missions per game. The objective of the blue team is to win 3 out of 5. For the spies, it's to sabotage 3 out of 5.

The start player chooses which people go on a mission, depending what the mission parameters are. If you are a blue, you must vote for the success of the mission. If you are a spy, you MAY vote for the success or failure. This is done with cards that are handed to the start player who then shuffles them up (keeping who put what in secret).

This game is a blast on just puts you on the edge of your seat. Although, you can only play so many games before you stop caring. Never do more than two consecutive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game has been SO FUN every time we've played, though it is a bit of a chore to explain the rules. Its like werewolf/mafia but without player elimination so everyone gets to play the whole game which is a plus. 

Only gripe is that it seems unbalanced. It seems way too hard for the Resistance to win. The Spies bluff and double bluff and its basically impossible to figure out who is who after that. Regardless its still heaps of fun even if the resistance never/hardly wins! :) Its the journey not the destination that counts :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Close to being the perfect game for the group I regularly play with. Shifting group dynamics, developing patterns of play over time, and the birth of the term 'rat' for any hidden traitor in any game...  There's a lot to love.

Like: How satisfying the game feels on both sides, either through successful deduction or convincing deception. With the mechanics of the game being quite simple, the social element is what makes the largest part of the game, and there's a lot of scope for creativity in play style on both sides. Coordinating with your team, known or unknown, can be challenging but satisfying. Getting a read on people (and successfully convincing other people), or giving people the wrong read on you, feels very rewarding.

Dislike: Due to playing it so much, it can be hard to introduce a newer player to the game despite it being a pretty simple game - sometimes it's them not grasping simple rules, sometimes it's them not grasping the subtlety of play (accepting/rejecting missions in particular). Players not quite being mindful of the team they're on can be costly, particularly a good player who is warned they're acting ratty and persists with it. The occasional instance of the good team lucking into correct selections quickly isn't great, but is unavoidable now and then.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great for family nights and parties!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you are a person that usually does not like social deduction games, you might want to try this game before you dismiss it.  This game succeeds where so many other games fail.  There is no player elimination, no need for constant shutting of eyes, the voting is simple and quick and very organized.  The best part for me is that the game is extremely balanced.  When I first played I was worried that with varying numbers of people that one side would have the advantage.  To my surprise and delight, regardless of the number of people I have seen both sides win consistently.

RATING: 8.1
Aug10:

I do not like:
Werewolf/Mafia
Bang
Shadow Hunters
etc.

And yet this is a game I can get behind.  Why?

Because you have partial information dammit!  Shadow Hunters did that somewhat too, but the rules overhead was way too much.  The Resistance is nice and simple to understand.

And yet the implications of the game can run so dang deep.

Instead of blind accusations you all start jumping through logic puzzles of "if this then that BUT"!

It's quite the enjoyable player interaction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This one was a slow burn. The first few times I played it, it really fell flat. I'm not sure if it was the group dynamic, or a few bad eggs spoiling the fun, but I was really beginning to wonder why it gets the love it does, and chalking it up as an inexpensive shot in the dark that didn't pan out. 

...then we tried it again, and it was good. Then again, and it was even better. Then again, and again, and again, and the game just kept improving with every single play. It's a marvelously simple and incredibly tense game. The whole game is entirely social and political: is one able to read other people and keep from being read? Is one able to convince others of one's intentions, or conversely fool them into trust?

I really appreciate how distilled of a game experience it is. No roles. No host. No bits. Just a simple question: who can you trust? This game absolutely murders Werewolf for me, and has definitely become a group favorite. It gets a ton of play, and I'm happy to bring it out at any gathering. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very good game built off Werewolf with the secret voting mechanic from BSG thrown in.  The nice thing here is it plays well even with 5 (better with more), no elimination AND you do not need a moderator.  Everything else is more or less the same as WW with great bluffing elements, psychology at work and lots of accusations.  Somewhat more info here though especially with special abilities too so you potentially have [i]something[/i] to build accusations off of.  

Curious to see the produced version and what new cards will be included (hopefully some good options) and if they help balance the game more to the resistance a little.  Very fun game as is WW and worth owning even if you already have WW for the differences mentioned and most likely goodies coming in the produced package.  

Rating could go up once I play the produced version

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a social deduction game and I'm not a big fan of them but it's not bad for what it is.  The players each get a secret loyalty card.  Most of them are members of the underground (sci-fi theme) while a few are spies.  Each round one person is the team leader and picks a team for a mission.  Everyone votes whether to accept the team.  Then the team puts in secret mission cards that are then shuffled.  Each card either indicates success or failure.  The mission only succeeds if all are successes.  If a spy has secretly sabotaged it everyone starts trying to guess who it was to keep them from being on the next mission leading to much kerfuffle.  The resistance has to win a certain number of missions to (say 3 of 5) otherwise the spies win.  To make it more fun, we had a house rule that before team leader dramatically flipped each mission card s/he would make up what the mission was about and what each step was (e.g., unleashing killer clowns on the Evil Regime so first step is recruit clowns, then equip them with laser flowers, etc) to make a story of it.  Overall fun.  More a party game.  I prefer Secret Hitler or One Night Werewolf as they have more interesting things going on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
What makes a good bluffing game for me is when a player has to back up any table talk with in-game actions. I want to like The Resistance, but it is just a little too free-form for me to enjoy it. It is difficult to actually get information about who is bluffing and who is telling the truth because so little actual gameplay takes place. And the cost of information is too high - by the time a player starts revealing enough information to demonstrate loyalty to one side or the other, the outcome is almost determined.

I understand this game's popularity - it's easy to teach and supports a large group - but there are so many other great bluffing games that I'd rather play than The Resistance, a game that mostly involves sitting at a table and arguing with people about intentions rather than interpreting actions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ah, The Resistance. My favorite game.

We've had some amazingly good times. We've had some dramatically bad times. There have been ups and there have been plenty of downs. We've had people storm out of the room, cursing, declaring they would never play the game again. We've had people sit and look at their phone the entire game. I've had some of my favorite gaming memories, staring into my friends' eyes, trying to read there every movement and breath. This game has created friendships, torn them apart, and rebuilt them. Resistance is more than a game to us. Resistance is the foundation that has brought us together.

But, alas, no matter how many times we say that we're completely DONE with Resistance, we always come back for more. We just can't stay away. I would like to say a very warm thank you to Resistance for providing numerous hours of enjoyment to my gaming group.

Games Played: 1300+ 
(Most of them logged: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/playstats/thing/41114)

RATING: 7
I was initially very skeptical about this game, but it works very well where Werewolf breaks down:  it forces interaction and discussion among any group of players by presenting itself in a manner where everyone's motives are clearcut.

Compare to Are You the Traitor, which results in people like me sitting there, totally speechless and not caring as to what happens, The Resistance effectively involves everyone from the start.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This comment is for the First Edition of the game.

2012-03-09

Initial Rating: 8.5 (October 2010)

I love hidden roles games and The Resistance plays so quick it is a winner in my book. The game is pretty fun to play. It has similar, but improved, mechanics than its parent game Werewolf. 1. In The Resistance the votes are secret. 2. There is no player elimination. 3. You don’t need a storyteller which I hate to be in Werewolf.

Very easy to teach, great to introduce new people to the hobby.

Perhaps my only concern is that it appears that winning the game is a lot harder for the resistance, still win or lose we always have a blast playing this so it is a very minnor issue for me

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2012-04-17

Now I have more plays of The Resistance under my belt, I still enjoy it tremendously and I would love to play it more often, it appears I was correct in my previous assessment and The Resistance loses more often than not. Except for a huge mistake from the empire players you can never be sure who are they (unless you are one of them obviously :devil:) and that worries me a little because if the empire plays perfectly there is no way for them to lose. I have to say I have played with the Plot Cards twice (so I don’t know for sure if they address this issue or not) and I hope they offer a solution to my dilemma BUT even if it is not the case I still will continue to play the game, it is just too fun to pass. 

I love how this game allows me to manipulate the situation to my advantage. Great game.

Current  Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2012-11-27

Last Saturday I played The Resistance: Avalon and I really liked it. If you are new to The Resistance, Avalon is the edition you need to get, as it is exactly the same as the Resistance base game BUT it has some variants that make the game a lot better.

If you already own The Resistance, you can easily play the Avalon variant version making little changes so I cannot justify buying both editions. (Although perhaps I will anyway :D).

I like more The Resistance theme (dystopian future) than the Avalon one (fantasy setting).

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2014-06-17

I ended up buying The Resistance: Avalon :D. I LOVE this game. When we are playing with new gamers, I usually play vanilla Resistance, but if we are playing in an experienced group, we usually play the Avalon edition. I still haven’t played much with the Plot cards, that is my next goal. 

The Resistance is still a great game (but Avalon is a bit better) so I’m downgrading its rating a bit to reflect this. I won’t ever say no to a Resistance game though.

Also, I prefer the first Resistance edition than the second one, mainly because the 1st edition is much more portable in a deck box AND the chips from the second one peel off easily. You can also read my comments for the second edition under my profile. 

Current Rating: 8.0
[hr]
2017-12-11

I continue to love the game, but as I have played it many (MANY) times, my desire to play it again has decreased a bit. I still think it is the best game in its genre and I will gladly play it all the time.

One of 2009´s favorites.

Current Rating: 7.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This comment is for the Second Edition of the game.

2012-11-27

Initial Rating: 8.5 (November 2012)

I think this is a great game. The only difference between the editions are the components. In the second edition the components are updated and they are really nice, you now have a “board” for each number of players and more tokens, tokens for voting, tokens to choose your team, tokens to track the round and the numbers of disagreements in the current round. All of these is nice to have but not really necessary. 

On the bad side, this box is bigger than the one of the first edition, making it a little harder to travel with it.

Bottom line, I don’t feel any compulsion of getting the second edition if I already own the first edition. But if you are a first comer to The Resistance this is the way to go.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2014-06-17

I prefer the first Resistance edition than the second one, mainly because the 1st edition is much more portable in a deck box AND the chips from the second one peel off easily.

Current Rating: 8.0

One of 2009´s favorites.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9.75
Incredible game - my gaming group would not stop playing this -- we played over and over again for an entire weekend and every game was tons of fun, provided a huge amount of laughs, and left us wanting to start up again. At its core the Resistance was a game of bluffing, player reading and psychology. It was fun to see how players behaved different when they were a member of the resistance versus their behavior when they were trying to sabotage the group. Adding in the plot thicken cards slightly reduces reliance placed on the psychological/player reading nature of the game and I recommend putting them in. Seeing two players confront one another after one has looked at their allegiance card and still not knowing which one is telling the truth was an incredible experience!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

UPDATE: Over it.  I can play this game forever.  The new kickstarter expansions should really help.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The Resistance is a 'social' game, where most of the game is spent talking or not talking. The game is similar to Werewolf where players are given roles secretly and then sent on missions to bring down the corrupt government. Players on the Resistance are trying to send only loyal rebels on these missions, while preventing the Spies from joining in on the fun. The Spies seek to sabotage the missions by deflating the excitement of the Resistance members through sabotage, miscommunication, and general all-around dickery.

One 'thing' about The Resistance however, is the fact that the meta game will decide most games before it even begins. Players who were previously Spies will be accused of being Spies in another game simply because they were Spies in a previous game and their behaviour did not change.

The Resistance is a good game that plays well in larger groups. The social aspect may deter some from enjoying the game as they may not be used to lying, cheating and deceiving other people to get what they want. For those who eat, live and breathe deception, The Resistance is gold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Surprisingly deep.  It does a great job of creating conflict very quickly and the game doesn't drag on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Update Dec 2011: 25 plays in and it's wearing thin. Still good, but feels repetitive and a lot less fun than it used to. 'You're a spy!' 'No, you're a spy!'
------------
No, not The Muse album, my new favourite game.

How come something this quick and simple can be this good? I thought Werewolf and Saboteur were ace, but this takes the 'hidden mole' game to a new level.

I asked Robert to show me how it played towards the end of York's Beyond Monopoly club session yesterday and we pulled in a few others for a quick game. 3 hours and many missed trains later, we stopped playing it after over a dozen games, while all the time the number of players grew attracted by the good time we were clearly having!

The base game with 5 or 6 easily merits a 10, but I'd mark down the 'Plot Thickens' cards used to balance the game with larger groups as: 1. they slow down the game flow, and 2: they balance the game by giving the resistance team some lucky pot-shots at identifying the spies. In our last game the spies lost purely on one of the 'Plot Thickens' cards giving the resistance a 100% chance of identifying the remaining spy on the last turn.

But that's a minor blot. If you like social games, enjoy bluffing and deduction, and have active senses of drama and humour, this one's a winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
The resistance takes the game Werewolf and makes it fun for the whole group. No physical player elimination, tons of strategy, and a good way to learn about your friends.

You can be loud or quiet, aggressive or passive, and you can still have fun. I'm sure it's not for everyone, but it is my top party game. Best played with 8 players.

RATING: 6.2
I have played this game a lot. With the right group, it becomes an overly-deep analysis of people, their reactions, voting patterns. This gives you a lot to work with, even without the in-built expansion.

As of yet, I prefer the base game to the expansion, Avalon, or any other rules twist. Personally, I think Avalon turns the game from the fun of Werewolf social deduction to the dryness of Poker.

I for one highly recommend this game, and look forward to many more plays.

Why I need to re-rate this: Okay, it's about a 6.9 but I want to give it a chance with the expansion

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Interesting social deduction game, which is not overly long (due to limited rounds) and can get pretty involved if people start analyzing things. But this can only happen after a few games under the players' belts, as at first you do not try to strategize during your choices (too much). And the game experience also depends on the group itself - whether the players like to throw (sometimes outrageous) accusations around, or only play it mechanically. In the latter case it would be pretty boring. In the former - way to go! Have yet to try it myself, but will definitely bring it to a future game session.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For me to give a game a "10" is rare. 10 means I will always be willing to play it over anything else, besides another 10. This one is one of my favorites.

This is a straightforward bluffing/deduction/hidden traitors game that has a few things in common with the werewolf/mafia party games you can play with a pen and paper. What I prefer about this version is there is no player elimination, so nobody is left sitting waiting for 20 minutes like can happen in werewolf or mafia.

By far the favorite in my gaming group. We come back to this one again and again. After several playthroughs with the same group, the expansions become necessary, but add enough novelty to keep it going. Different combinations of different expansions also yield very different games.

I will also say that my gaming group is a loose collective of people, and different nights will have different attendance. This game has proven time and again to be the best way to acquaint strangers for the evening. Several times I have invited say a new friend from my job, and they begin the evening quiet and shy, but ten minutes into a game of Resistance they are totally comfortable pointing a finger at their new fellow gamers and shouting "spy!" It's a great time.

One caveat: this game is NOT for quiet or shy types. Introverts will likely feel pressured and/or just plain hate the experience. It requires a great deal of discussion and interaction - and if you're a spy - acting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Good traitor game, but the formality of it reduces the fun compared to Werewolf.  This sort of game you can play two ways:  either like Werewolf, as a fun romp; or as a true deduction game.  The problem is that its only fun if everyone playing is of the same mindset on which of the two ways to play, and that just doesn't happen.  I don't have a preference for either - both can be fun - but if one person wants to play it as a romp and others as a deduction (or vice-versa) then it just does not work.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
BSG after being boiled down to its essence.  Was fun the one time I played it and was totally thrown by a tricksy spy.  

from a geeklist after game night 6/12/2011: 
i checked my collection just now to make sure i had resistance at 10.  then i considered downgrading another of my tens to show props to the big R, but did not (b/c i only have two other 10s).  

i understand why there's been some backlash in our group against it recently, but here's why i think this game is probably most mostest favorite of all right now: 
* [b]it's always different, and always in fucked up challenging new ways.[/b]  i feel like every game i have to ask someone to read me back his logic on a particular call 2x b/c i'm sure there's a point there, it's unfamiliar to me, and i want to get it.  then i have to figure out if i'm just missing the point or if tom is F'ing with me b/c he's a desperate spy or if he's trying to signal me as a chill morpheus or if he's just being sleepy-drunk.  

*  [b]it's the game we play that's most about interacting with each other.[/b]  Can there be any doubt?  we joke and talk quite a bit during our JASE games too, but this game is about the social, and i think any game group could use more of that.  and that's what will always make this game refreshing in a 12 hour gamenight.

*  [b]the game is great at giving you a bunch of info, very little of it clean.[/b]  and the info you have that IS clean is usually clean only for you and not for anyone else.  i think the power has clearly swung blue for us as we've gotten better, but i think that's due for a shift b/c of this information gap.  i personally will be going to a 5 day seminar this week in order to improve my skills as spy. 

okay, i was just thinking on last night's games and wanted to toss some praise where it's due.  there are downsides, including a) some player's uncomfortable experiences with playing roles, b) it feels really unfriendly when we bring in new players or inexperienced gamers (joe's boss and husband, ed, eli's lady friend) b/c they don't know what's going on and they eventually just want it all to end, c) the feeling that a 7+ player game is being dominated by only a few.  

that said, F that, this game is the shit!  which is why 4 weeks from last night the game night at my house will consist of 12 hours of resistance mwahahhahahhaah (not intended as a factual statement).

RATING: 10
Just a spectacular game. Tight and engaging while also being easy to learn and teach. Best part being that so much of the game is played “above the table” reading your friends or lying to their faces. It’s not for everyone. Certainly, conflict or deception averse players need not apply. But I have just never had a game blow people’s minds the way the first couple turns of their first game of this does. Note: if you don’t mind an Arthurian Fantasy theme, Avalon has everything here plus the AMAZING Merlin/Assassin variant (though, honestly, it’s pretty easy to house rule that into The Resistance and it was officially released in an expansion).

RATING: 6
The Resistance just adds enough elements to Werewolf to give a few hints for deducting the secret roles from gameplay itself and not only from the metagame between the players which can sink Werewolf easily if the majority of players are calm. It's still easier to hide your spy identity when you stay out of most discussions but now others will have some specific evidence to tackle those kind of players. Luckily, it avoids Battlestar Galactica's chrome and length overkill and stays within 15-30 minutes playtime making it a good opener or closer for game nights. Now, I just have to learn how to play a traitor without being discovered each time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fantastic substitute for Werewolf, especially when you have a smaller number of players.  While being eliminated early in Werewolf can be annoying, I still enjoy it as I can observe and learn about the players.  But for those that dislike player elimination, the Resistance also delivers on that front as well.

The only concern I have about the game is the level of difficulty of winning as Resistance.  Having to get everything perfect can be very tricky as there are only three bases to lose.  I will probably try one of the recently posted variants.

I would gladly buy a version of this if it was released by a game company.

Update - 12/10.  Now that the published version has been released and I have played it with more people, I am very comfortable moving the rating up to a 9, with a possible move up to 10.  It really is the perfect negotiation game.  Sometimes I find that people will not want to play because it's such an intense game, involving so much lying for the spies that it can be physically and mentally exhausting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5

However, wasn't sure who the remaining one was, but had some people who I sure about.  

Ended up voting yes for two parties, thankfully convincing folks to go for the last one.  (Also proved my innocence by pointing out that one of the earlier parties would have to have a spy).  

I wonder how often that happens.  Still good for large groups, although I also fear it could run long.

RATING: 7.5

It’s easy to teach and learn, and people are quickly up to speed on the mechanics - though the deduction takes a while longer to understand. The suspicion and accusation means that players have to feel comfortable with one another, because if someone feels a bit socially isolated in the group, this may not be such an enjoyable experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The grand-daddy of bluffing games as far as I can tell. Some of the most memorable game sessions I've played have had Resistance as a centerpiece. 

In a nutshell: some players are Resistance and some are Spies. The Resistance wants to successfully complete three missions, and the Spies want three missions to fail (first to 3 wins). Missions are passed or failed based on what "team" goes on them, which is proposed by the "team leader", a rotating position. Everyone votes Yes or No on who's on the team. If it passes, the mission carries through, the team members put in either a "Pass" or "Fail" card anonymously and the results of that determine if the mission succeeds. Generally only 1 "Fail" is required for it to fail.

This game has some of the deepest, richest meta-game of anything I've ever played. Succeeding at the game requires attention to whose on the missions and their outcome, how individuals vote on specific team proposals, and more. The depth to which the game allows for interesting scenarios to arise is robust to say the least. Of course, successful bluffers will have more skill at being a Spy.

HOW DOES IT COMPARE TO SECRET HITLER?? This game is better than Secret Hitler for a number of reasons. I've played dozens of rounds of each and what I've found is that Resistance rewards diligence and effective strategy far more than Secret Hitler does. On top of that, the two Resistance expansions (Hidden Agenda and Hostile Intent) add even greater options for strategy with new roles and parameters. If you're going to get one, make it this one. It's also cheaper than Secret Hitler, even with all the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent game.  This is the game that werewolf should have been.  Traitor mechanic, but there is a known number of traitors, there is actual information that can be used to determine which players are the traitors.  Also, unlike SoC or BSG, the game is over fairly quickly, which means that you get to play again.  Huzzah!

Oct 2011:  I have been playing this game often with high school students.  They absolutely love it, though there is a definite disparity in understanding of the game.  Weak spies are much worse than weak resistance.  A weak spy can pretty much end the game for their team.

May 2012:  A 7-player game with all experts is ridiculously enjoyable.  I have a class where I get to play such games.  It is incredible.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
There are a number of spectrums games exist on.  Once is the "play the other players" or "play the game mechanics" spectrum.  Some games manage to have a fair amount of both.  A lot of euros have you playing against the game mechanics.  This game is the opposite.  You primarily play the other players.  Of course the mechanics come into play, but the experience you have will be HIGHLY dependent on who you play with.  I think the game is at its best with a group of people who are comfortable with one another.  It helps if the group has a mix of "class clown" and analytical types.

I always enjoy it though, and it's one of the games of mine that people always reference after they've played it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Picked this game up on clearance from target for about $6 after tax. I had doubts about the game although interested after watching the table top episode on it. I didn't believe that anyone in my gaming group would get into it. Didn't think they had the chops to really role play. Man I was wrong. We played like 10 games in one night. This game was just to be an opener to playing other games but it took over our evening. It was a blast, lots of laughs and by the last game I couldn't trust what anyone was saying it was great.

One of the great moments is when I convinced my friend I was on the resistance, same as him, we both voted the same way agreed who should go on the mission and even located one of the spies. It was great when the final mission came down to him, one other and myself and he discovers I was the spy and won the game.

This game has so much potential, but definitely requires people open to the experience. It is an experience and you have to participate.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A game about deception and deduction. Two teams race for best-out-of-5. "Good" players must try to learn the identities of others, while the "bad" players knows the identities and are trying to confuse the "good" players. The game requires a LOT of table tall, information sharing, and each player should feel comfortable about lying. Very mind-tiring game and requires everyone to be at the same level, else it would be a frustrating game. 7+ players recommended.
The additional "play resistance cards" role is confusing and unclear. Most people I played with preferred to ignore them and rather just play the base game.

Replay Value: 3
Difficulty: 2
Time: 30-60 minutes

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A revolutionary game design, that brought Werewolf/Mafia in to smaller group play, and made it better in the process. This is a 'modern classic' with wide appeal.

It is a fun team game of bluffing, lying, calculating, and generally having a great time. Every group I've played with has memorable Resistance stories.

Unlike Werewolf, where a small group of people dominate a larger, mostly silent, group, The Resistance requires everyone to get involved. It's intimate, explosive, and hilarious, but it's still just as much a game as a social experience.

I would play this whenever the opportunity presented itself, especially with people I've just met, as it is a great way to get to know a little about other people's personalities.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great alternative to Werewolf.  Werewolf is essentially trying to influence a group-think, mob-mentality and progress is made by player eliminations.  The Resistance has no player elimination and is guided by deduction to determine who amongst us are loyal versus traitors/spies, by voting for missions.  Like Werewolf, it is a social-deduction game not unlike poker.  If you are a Werewolf fan, this is an excellent alternative and I'd gladly play both in appropriate gaming situations.  Also, I know many who do not enjoy Werewolf but like this instead.  I really like both and don't see it as similar games, but view both as having social deduction elements/mechanisms (it's akin to saying that Age of Steam and Ticket To Ride are the same b/c they're railroad games, but in my mind, both are very different).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
LIKE:

* This doesn't feel anything like Werewolf which I despise.  
* This game is over in about 20 minutes!
* There is still the whole element of trying to figure out who is who and the fun table talk and paranoia.
* Can't argue with the price point.
* Appears to play 5-10 equally well.

DISLIKE:

* If people aren't paying attention, they will lose the game for their team, almost guaranteed.  I probably shouldn't diss the game for this, but it can be painful.

RATING: 5
A better take on the Werewolf style party game that adds more game to the mix. What it adds is greatly appreciated as it gives the game mroe meat to chew on, and definitely more active choice making rather than the fly by the seat of your pants accusations that run rampant in Werewolf. Definitely the best of the bunch that I have played so far, but overall this style of game is not something that I am a huge fan of. It ultimately boils down to accusations after accusations even when insufficient data exists to make those accusations. As a data analyst, this just goes against my nature.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Like the subject matter but the game system itself has nothing relate to the theme.  The theme is merely a disguise to an deductive game, in which players get information from the signals given out each hand of the participating players.  As the number of players increases, the number of signals would multiply by five folds, ten folds or more.  During the signal receiving process, players get to talk to and out of each other, without knowing who are the true spies from the government, constantly destroying the "missions" of the Resistance.  The Resistance is the positive and righteous side in the game, not the vice versa, somewhat reflecting the current disbelief in the governement by the common people.  This type of game certainly would hit some gamers.  To me, however, the variations and the confusion of the signals from the players, are sometimes too much.  You need spend some time to figure out what's really going on underneath - as the spies would know each other and thus plot to destroy the missions of the Resistance.  It is a game about deceit, cunning and making deduction from the signals received in a very short time.  If you are into it, this is the game for you. It is a party game to me...not the one that I am finding much depth in.      
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
During the explanation, it is important to really describe the roles of the resistance and of the spies.  I would describe everything with a heavy use of them.  Some people were in fact confused by the "double negation": the spies try to counter the resistance, which tries to counter the government.  I was hard for them to know who the "bad guys" were.

It was easier to grasp the game with 5 people than with 10.  Plus, this increases the chances of some players not listening, or not understanding the rules.

I found it more enjoyable to be in the resistance, because you don't know who is who, and you have to guess.  When you're a spy, you know who's who, and therefore when to fail a leader's choice; and most of the time, you'll want to sabotage the mission if you can.

"While tactics and reads on players that have played together a lot have gotten stale, adding just one new player to the mix gives the variance that makes me expect to see this game around for the next 100 plays."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The Resistance is a bluff and voting game. Like the famous "Werewolves Of Miller's Hollow", each player will have a secret role, evil or good. The evil guys know who's who, but the good guys don't know anything.... The evil players will have to spoil the missions while the good ones will try to find who they are.
The game can be quite hard for the good players, especially if an evil player gains their trust.... But that's a very nice game, and doesn't take long to play once you've understood the rules!

RATING: 6

RATING: 7
Type: 5-10 player hidden traitor game where one team is trying to succeed in missions, while another team is trying to secretly sabotage and fail those missions.

Best with: 5+
Weight: light
Duration: 30-60 minutes
Notes:
lots of player lying involved; not for the shy
can be broken when playing without extra powers/rules by highly logical, deductive players
pretty quick game to play when discussion doesn't drag on

Resistance is a relatively simple party game for, preferably, 4-6 players. The game is pretty simple to start. Players are resistance fighters attempting to overthrow an oppressive corporation-government set in the distant future by going on successful missions. However, 2 players in this resistance group are not actual resistance fighters, but instead they are spies for the government, bent on subverting missions so they fail.

One upside to this game is how it gets pretty much everyone involved to some degree. There are plenty of pleadings of innocence and various degrees of trying to figure out which players are loyal or which players are spies.

One downside to this game applies largely to the basic game without any extra rules or expansion-like additions. Play this game too many times in a row, and you'll invariably have 1 or 2 players start to piece together the logic and begin to unravel the game as they "figure it out." This can be solved by adding in more complex rules, making the mission voting secret (as well as the mission results), or just not playing this game too much in succession on a given night.

When it works, this game is very fun. When it gets played too much and too simply with people who figure the game out, the fun dies very quickly.

Still, this is a really cool game for groups.

Similar games in my collection: One Night Ultimate Werewold (interactive role-based party game), The Resistance: Avalon (interactive role-based party game), Mascarade (interactive card-based party game), Say Anything (light party game), Deception: Murder in Hong Kong
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
We played it with 6 players many times (probably about 10) and all but one time the Spies won.  I am sure that we weren't very good.  Maybe,  would like it better if I played with some more experience players.

RATING: 8

There are a few in our group who are such bad liars that them as spies is almost a gimme but when it hits right - and more games are hits than misses- it really tears you up when you lose, the tension it creates with a minimal rule set is quite an achievement.

RATING: 8
This is a nice ARE YOU A WEREWOLF variant with a bit more narrative structure and a clever CLUE-like deduction element that makes the whole thing less reliant on blind guesswork and fakery than other similar party games. The components and art also really add to the experience; it's possible to play this quite dramatically. Minor complaints: tallying and redistributing the vote cards gets slightly fiddly, and it seem quite a bit easier for the spies to win - I recommend the "blind spies" variant as the more balanced version of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I cannot say enough good things about this game.  I have never played this where folks did not immediately want to play again.  It has gone over well with gamers and non gamers.  In fact, I think it goes over better with non games because the mechanics are so easy the game is fun.  You put together teams to go on missions, but you don't know who is in the resistance and who is a spy.  The open voting for mission team and secret voting for the missions give you some indication of who is a spy and who is not.  But often you think you know when you do not.  

The only down side to the game is that there can be some meta-gaming where you hear someone move or someone takes there time selecting a secret vote for a mission.  This is easily addressed by warning folks not to move and everyone mixing their mission votes prior to submitting.

RATING: 9
Fun game of social interaction and logic. There are two sides: resistance and spies. Resistance members must complete successfully most of the game's missions, trying to discover which ones are the undercover spies. The spies have to apply misdirection and subterfuge to sow dissent among the ranks, in order to be able to sabotage most of the missions without giving away their identity. Recommended.

RATING: 7
I'd heard so many good things about this game, and frankly I think it was worth getting, but I seem to have a hard time getting together the right group of people to play it.  I found if not everyone is ready to have the right mindset of diplomacy and intrigue (because some people just don't enjoy that kind of play anyways), the game falls flat, because the people on board win easily because the people not having any fun aren't creating the challenge needed to keep it interesting.

I would always be down for playing this game with the right people, and seeing how it's supposed to be played, but I think I just found I don't have enough of the right people around me to ever really enjoy this game, so it'd be better in other hands.

Traded with Poo! for Citadels.

THEN got it with the Coup Kickstarter with Avalon with the appropriate "Merlin" and "Assassin" promo cards.  This has been one of the best games to play with friends.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In a sense, this is the traitor concept boiled down to its bare bones. This is both good and bad. The good is that it is playable in a short amount of time, and with the right crowd, this game loses none of the deceit, lying, and accusations that make games such as Battlestar Galactica so fun, but takes only 30 minutes. The flipside of this is that the game really only works with players who will willingly engage in the social game. Whereas something like Battlestar Galactica has a strong theme, card and resource management, and an unfolding narrative to interest players and engage them, Resistance has none of that. It will either be a big hit with a group, or bomb completely.

That said, when it's a hit, it really is a fantastic game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
([url=www.meeplemart.com]Meeplemart.com[/url], 2011-04-08)

RATING: 7
A must game for a large group and always good to end the night with this or 1 night ultimate werewolf.I this game player will be dealt a either a loyal or traitor hidden card. The everyone votes on a mission and players go on that mission - the players on that mission then submit a success or failure card - it only take 1 failure for mission to fail.after each mission theres a group discussion and hopefully the loyalist can suss out who the traitors are.
 The only gripe about this is that the more verbal gamers tend to raise to the top of the pile - were the shy/thinking gamers among us tend not to enjoy it as much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
While this new game of large-group intrigue offers a clear improvement over the venerable Mafia/Werewolf in working without player elimination, it is extremely bare bones, at least in its basic form. There really is no more than a mechanic here, and while that voting/sabotage mechanic is very well done, it’s hard to get a lively game going on so little thematic incentive. A point of comparison of how much boiled down to the pure essentials this game is might be Dominion without the kingdom cards: just money and victory points. Still a working and even an innovative game, but certainly not using the basic idea to its full potential.

Another possible problem I see is that, at least for seven players, winning with the rebels seems to be nigh impossible - you need to identify three double agents with only two failed missions and make sure that mission control is in the right hands.

Perhaps both problems could be cured by the optional rules that come with the game, but I’m not sure whether I’m keen enough on it to find out. At least it’s quick, that can’t be denied.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

amazing for gamers and non-gamers sharing a table

RATING: 6.5
At one point, I'm pretty sure I rated this a 9.  I really just don't find the deduction in this game compelling.  It boils down to yelling at each other for 15-30 mins/game.  That used to be fun, but now I find it tiring.  Not the game for me, but a few of my friends really like it, mainly the ones that haven't played it as much as the rest of us.  Still gets played due to the wide player count, just not as many times in a night as before.

Much, much rather play One Night Ultimate Werewolf.

RATING: 9
I'm in love with this game. 10-15 minute games in which you'll lie, or be lied to. This game is stripped down to the bare necessities. A simple game system, but plenty of game to be had. It even works with my non-gamer friends.

One major caveat about the game is that you might need a group that can handle the potential consequences. Our games can get quite heated. At the end of a session, I find myself having to shake hands with someone I bashed heads with in the game.

RATING: 7
Great game of co-op and deceit. 5-10 players work together to try and complete successful missions for the resistance over 5 rounds. Each round a captain picks a team of players to secretly vote on whether a mission succeeds or not. Among those players may be a loyalist, who may vote for the mission to fail and bring the resistance 1 step closer to crumbling.

RATING: 8
A fast paced paranoia game similar to Werewolf but more fun. You either are part of the resistance or the spies, where each side's goal is to complete 3 successful missions. To determine who to send out for the mission is crucial to the success of the team. This is where the game outshines Werewolf because you have to choose wisely as opposed to guessing and lynching just for the fun of it. No moderator needed means everyone can enjoy the game as playing characters.

Note: Will update review after playing with the expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I wanted this to be "like Werewolf, but no one gets kicked out and has to watch," and it's definitely that -- but it's also more than that. Having two sets of data every round, from voting and then (if the vote passes) from mission cards, adds quite a bit of depth.

It's easy to teach, includes nice components, and plays in 5-15 minutes. It's different enough that I'll keep Werewolf on hand, but enough people in my group are frustrated with Werewolf that I see The Resistance taking its place.

...but after 6 plays, I have yet to see a resistance victory, and that includes using the blind spies variant on the sixth play. Slightly different group and definitely different spies each time, too. Seems too heavily weighted to the spies, unfortunately. Went from an 8 to a 6 on that basis, which is really too bad.

And a couple of months later, it went to the "Grr, this is kind of annoying" pile and got sold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This great party game is all about player interaction and mind games. This game has an endless supply of mental bluffing and accusation against others. Oh man this game gets our group heated. This game can put friendships on the ropes, and give you some trust issues. Pure verbal communication in this game, so it really fits outgoing personalites well. My group both loves and hates this game. It's player interaction and hidden role selection at its finest. And in a rather fast playing package might i add. outstanding game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I may have played this with too many players - it was seven or eight - but although it was kind of fun, it seemed that oddly it was both overly mechanical and overly random. Random because if the wrong cards came out, the resistance had no chance of winning. Overly mechanical because if the right cards came out it was all about deduction from the play and little or no bluff.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome game that takes the fun part of BSG, traitors, and turns that into quick 20-40minute standalone social deduction/bluffing exercise. For even deeper game you can use plot cards of 2nd edition that allow you to get more actual data to base claims on. Boardgaming perfection.

Update: When Resistance: Avalon came out I was ready to abandon the original forever as it added Werewolf-type roles into the system, which really improved the experience. Plain Resistance is.. plain. But now things aren't so simple anymore... Yes, with the new expansions that came out in late 2014, the original Resistance again becomes the best Resistance experience. The expansions add Avalon roles and promos to original Resistance and then MORE. Defector, Inquisitor and Assassin roles are the awesomest way to play. You can add Reverser on top of that for more chaos or Hunter module for deeper experience. I'm not sure about Trapper module, but I guess it's something to bring out every now and then, doesn't hurt to have options in one of the best games ever made! Yes, this is the ultimate version now. Only scenario where I'd buy Avalon is if you prefer the theme, won't play often and want to save money (at least two of three should apply), in all other scenarios goodbye Avalon.

Expansions:
+The Resistance: Hostile Intent
+The Resistance: Hidden Agenda

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Game in a Nutshell: A streamlined werewolf-like game of voting. 

Played as: 10 player

Pros: Puts player interaction at the forefront and does so in a compact amount of time. Can involve a bunch of people, lacks downtime and does not eliminate players. Not expensive.  

Cons: Takes a play to get the swing of it, so hopefully you don't lose anyone. Maybe I haven't played enough but my impression is there's not a lot of variety built in the design resulting in some same-yness from game to game.

Other: I'd love to try this with a smaller group. Also, I just need to try the game more period. I will say the game feels heavily weighted against the resistance.

Best Use: Werewolf for people with less friends.

RATING: 10
I enjoy werewolf, but the arbitrary eliminations of the first few rounds and the downtime for the victims really killed it for me. 
Resistance is a game of deception and bluffing. When a spy pulls it off, it can be the most amazing thing for both spy and resistance. "No way! It was you?!?!", there is no player elimination, and you get out of it what you put in. Sure there are always loud people, but you don't have to listen to them. Your vote counts!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
My kind of dumb: chaotic, shouty, irrational and quick. But for one problem, which is, of course, that there's no actual game here. It's five rounds of pointlessness that's saved from being a 1 by the fact that it's over so fast.

I'm tempted to say that it's a valiant attempt to make something that could be described as "Werewolf...but worse!" Except that in Werewolf there is a non-trivial chance that you will be mercifully murdered right away and thus be eligible to play a more intelligent game. War of the Ring would be perfect, but Candyland would suffice.

Five rounds, by the way, is not really enough time to develop a reasonable suspicion of anyone in the group. This is doubly true when you consider that the spies won't sabotage the first mission because it gives away too much information. So it's effectively only four rounds. I suppose there are miniscule clues one might pick up from other players--tells, if you will--that might give away allegiance. But that uncomfortable look on the face of the person across from you might simply be the sudden realization that he could be doing something more fun, like using the restroom.

It's best to just pick someone (at random, or on a hunch, or because he looks constipated, doesn't really matter) and keep shouting irrationally "Spy! Spy! That one! Spy!" until the game ends. Your "theory" will make about as much sense as anybody else's, and you might even convince someone that you're correct. This strategy has the virtue of being simple to implement and usable no matter which side you're on! The game is just that elegant! Then it will be over before you know it, so you can move on to something else.

You might want to pick a different game group, though. After all, this one saddled you with The Resistance, so it's likely full of dullards and Eurogamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Absolute brilliance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Had a lot of fun with this one. The girlfriend and I made kickass spies, but I'll have to train her to stop giggling when she gets her spy card. She giggled whenever she closed her eyes, so it didn't give the other players any assistance in finding the real spies, but it certainly gave her a lot of unwanted attention. Not to say it was unwelcome, a laugh was had by all, but we'll be nigh unstoppable if I can teach her to hold a poker face!

RATING: 9
This game holds up to 10 people, and immediately, you're in cahoots. You are either part of a conspiracy, or you know that someone else - maybe someone you love or trust - is in on it. This is one of those fantastic little party games to pull out when you have a lot of friends around, beer happened, and you want to play something light but deeply engaging without having to first explain what a hit point is. It succeeds very well at what it tries to do, with very few moving parts, and that is a marvel.

RATING: 9
An excellent Social Deduction game, and the game that takes Werewolf to the next level. It's this game that really modernized the Werewolf formula and makes it a much, much better genre. Taking out player elimination is the first great thing this game does, and after that it becomes a race to complete missions for your side. It's not very well-balanced in the basic game and tends to favor the Empire Spies, but the advanced game with power cards lets you play this with a good skill component.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Not usually the type of game I enjoy but there's something about the quickness of the rounds, the deduction and the tabletop that put's this over the top in the Werewolf family of games. Find a fun group, not too timid to accuse other players and bluff, in order to make this game shine.

RATING: 8.5
Great party game. Can't beat it!

Unfortunately, my acquaintances solely want to play this. Happy to pull it out each time, but I bring other games for a reason! 

Still, well worth the money and a great game

*edit* bringing it up to an 8.5 from an 8. This game is the perfect "cooldown" game after an intense 3-4 hour gaming session. Nice and light and fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Plays a lot like Mafia (even more so than Bang!). The biggest differences are that there isn't any combat (like there is in Bang!), if you're outed as a spy you aren't kicked out of the game, and each game goes on for at most 5 rounds. Makes for quick games that includes each person in each round, with just as much mind games as Mafia has.

That said, I can't help but think just how little you actually need to play the game. The game doesn't really come with anything too special that you can't just replicate with a normal poker deck.

RATING: 5
Not sure I get it. This game is probably highly dependent on the group. I felt the accusations were random and no one listened to logic. The bad guys won every time, by a mile. Not really my sort of game.

After some observation and discussion, I think this game might be fun a little less than half the time; that is, fun for a little less than half the players; that is, fun for the spies. I've never played a spy, but I can see where that side must employ strategy and secrecy to accomplish their goal, where as the deduction that the resistance players must employ is done in such a vacuum (except in extreme lucky cases, which might be even less fun) that it doesn't feel strategic.
