=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Vote for mission teams and mission success to destroy the Empire/Resistance.

Plays: 4.
Type: Political deduction game = A game that is played by discussion where you attempt to deduce something through elimination.
Complexity: Light.
# of players: 6-10.
Playing time: See BGG.
Player interaction: Cooperation in the Resistance and between the Imperial spies. Competition for scarce resources - missions. Misdirection. Some cards that target other players specifically.
Randomness: Low – plot card draw, but these are optional and not decisive.

Replayability: High, it's quick so why not go again? The meta-game gets more interesting with repeat sessions as well.
Fun: Definitely. Nervous laughters abound. Deception can be fun.
Memorability: Good, you're playing your opponents and not a board, which makes for a memorable experience.

Thematic integration: Decent.
Components: Functional.

Who will like this: Large gaming groups.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
BSG in 30 minutes? Sign me up! Well, not quite. It's true that this game manages to retain a lot of BSG's paranoia, but by stripping everything else out of the design the paranoia feels a bit meaningless. It also doesn't build to the fever pitch BSG can achieve, primarily because of the reduced length, I think. I bet this works great for some groups; for mine, it hit the trade shelf almost instantly.

RATING: 8
BSG + Werewolf = backstabby goodness
-----------------------------------
First play was nine people - and it was all kids, so this game probably was less subtle, and unraveled more quickly than it probably would have if I was playing with careful and intelligent plays. I think this rating could go up with further players, but right now, it just doesn't seem to have the subtlety to it that Castle of the Devil has.
-----------------------------------
Ratings bump up after a few more plays with fewer players, and more strategy. Somehow deeply intense and frustrating and fun this time, and everyone really liked it.

------------------------------------

Another ratings bump upward. I like this more than any other secret traitor game I own. It's fiften to thirty minutes of accusation, yelling, treachery, and and deduction and it never ever ceases to please.
------------------------------------

Ratings bump back downward. I have over 30 or 40 unrecorded plays of this since it gets players five or six times each week with kids in gaming club. I am starting to see certain patterns playing out in it, because of the short playing time and the werewolf like nature of it, that are making it feel rote. Yes, it compresses the BSG experiences into fifteen minutes, but in doing so it loses some of the strategic depth available to clever cylons in BSG. In Resistance, either I am clever and can trick you, or the players get lucky, and win, and there is no middle ground. At least in BSG there is an end game where it all hangs in the balance, and a chance for humans to pull off a victory with careful cooperation and timing. I will continue to say yes to games of The Resistance, but it's shortcomings make it deserve a down grade in ratings here now.

RATING: 5
A simple paranoia game with a tacked on sci-fi theme, Resistance is simple enough for newbs and quick enough to fit the filler gap at the end of the night.

Like the idea (which reminds me somewhat of Werewolves) but its event cards don't really work for the game. Most of the time there's just not enough time to really work out who's who- it's all just blind accusation and guesswork with the game ending just as it starts to get interesting.

Wonder how it plays with rules variations and larger groups...

RATING: 3
"Werewolves without player elimination? Sign me up!"

On paper, The Resistance offers moderately more interesting decisions than Werewolves do, since a traitor can choose to not sabotage a mission. But the reality is less glorious and points at other flaws of the hidden role party games genre: all the roleplay is irrelevant to the actual gameplay and only works because some people have a harder time figuring out their probabilities and need convincing. Once you do, the game is over.

RATING: 9.2
Best of the Mafia/Werewolf genre for up to 10 players.

- no player-elimination, all can participate until the end
- much more "fuel" for discussion and deduction and "meta"-deduction evolving from the gameplay

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The Resistance is another 'traitor' game that actually works really well. It's broken down in to missions and involves trying to figure out which players are the Spies within in the group, based on the success or failure of the missions. The spies are constantly trying to sabotage them, but without revealing themselves. It's a good game, especially for larger groups of up to 10 people. Personally, if games where you love to lie and accuse are your thing, I'd recommend One-Night Ultimate Werewolf or Spyfall over this, however it definitely has it's place. There's a nice dystopian theme to it and very few games accomodate such big groups so well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I feel, by the date of typing this, that the Resistance has met it's match. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.75
The grandfather of the best line of social deduction games.  The only game better in this genre is Moriarty's Machinations.  I actually prefer the base game to Avalon because Merlin usually only allows the spys/minions a second chance to win.  However, I appreciate the depth the extra roles provide and realize that Percival in Avalon helps mitigate the Merlin-effect.  However, the new expansions have fixed the only problem with this version because now the Avalon roles are in the Sci Fi settings they should be in.  The expansions also add plenty of new ways to play.

Without those, however, this is still the 2nd best social deduction game.  There is beauty in the simplicity.  It is the job of the resistance to figure out the spys by seeing how they vote on who goes on missions.  From there, you must question and try to catch spys in lies.  That is all you need for this game to shine.

This game is not perfect.  If you play with quiet people that don't want to participate or just go along with whatever happens, the game falls apart a little bit.  That is a minor flaw with most social deduction games, so this game is still one of the best ever in my eyes.  Some may like that lighter form of play, anyway, but those are the type that might enjoy Bang: the Dice Game or similar games more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Inspired by Werewolf, players are either members of the Resistance or are spies, and these identities are secret, though the spies will know who the other spies are.  Each turn a leader proposes a mission with a number of. Everyone first votes to see if they approve the mission or not. Spies may fail a mission, while Resistance members may not. If there are 3 failed missions, the spies win, otherwise, if there are 3 succesful missions, the Resistance wins. 

I do like it more than Werewolf, since you do not get eliminated. There is also an element of deduction as well. It's a fun party type game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best party game as long as you're with the right people. This has been the fuel for some excellent evenings with friends.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love all bluffing games and especially secret identity games. This seems awesome!
Update: Played and own print out version, buying the proper version. Everything about this game is perfect in a genre of games which I consider near perfect. Possibly best of it's type.

like Once upon a time, Aye Dark Overlord, Are you the Traitor/Werewolf, the Resistance or any similar game, these are perhaps my favorite genre of game. They REQUIRE the right group. Right group is a euphemism for people who actually have some inkling of roleplaying, charisma, fun, wit, humor, exuberance, and amicability than this game wins wins wins. Which also means that if your group doesn't like these games, it might be time to get new friends rather than a new group because it's literally their fault and not the brilliant game.

RATING: 6.5
Deduce the saboteurs identity! But to do so you need to sift through all the tomfoolery as they lie their way to the bitter end. A party game that supports many players (up to ten) is quick and highly social. Similar game format as Werewolf, but is more controlled and structured. This is good, but comes at the cost of having more cards and components; which can be lost and or damaged given its a party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Great hidden role, and my first owned extremely good game. 

Issues: Game can end up in a coin flip between 2Ps, first mission never has information, seating can make a difference, plot cards are imbalanced and impersonal and change the game too much to a game of optimizing them, and an app wouldn't hurt.

Still amazing game and fun to combine/mix n match with Avalon. I like the theme of rebels against a government, but it doesn't really show through gameplay. Avalon's theme makes more sense I'd say, and I think I like it more too. Overall still amazing espionage game, esp. great for beginners/as a gateway.

Plays: 25+

I feel like for me, even with my Avalon cards and promos proxied, this game too often flops. Many people dont like the social deduction pressure and people are uncomfortable lying and bluffing. Snd if its mathed out, it just becomes not as fun. The variance of time can go up to an hour or so too, which is a bit long imo. But mainly the pressure of lying/being merlin/not working with certain people makes me want to sell this. I dont get the same rambunctious laughs as I do when I initially played nor am I overly crazy of the deductions and such which at times feel like it ends up as a coin flip ultimately. I think I actually prefer bluffing games like Coup or Sheriff of Nottingham over this game at least, though I like this one's lack of elimination. But Id like something more like faster gameplay or more excitement or more player powers. Also at higher played counts, I can split up the group if its a gaming group. Trading now.

RATING: 9
I love this game because I am able to bring it out so often and have a blast every time I play it.

I made my own family themed version of this and gave it as a white elephant gift during a family Christmas party. It was played at least 30 times over that Christmas break by my family. Needless to say it was a huge success.

This game is now requested every time the family gets together and has completely replaced the standard 5 crowns or other more basic card games for them.

I often get headaches after a few rounds because I get so tense. I'm horrible at this game as I tend to be too loud and no one listens to anything I'm saying but I love every second of it.

After multiple plays with the same group the meta game starts to get pretty deep and that is why I don't ever see myself getting tired of this.

Any game that can mechanically allow this to happen (players not PLAYING!) gets a 2 in my book (will never play again). The only reason it's not a 1 is because the game components are decent (they aren't printed on napkins) and it allows for a high # of players.

RATING: 2
This is a good game... but I will never play it again. 

Spies need to be able to lie, and I'm a terrible liar. Resistance members need to be able to read people, and I can't read people.

Most good games that I feel I'm bad at I search for areas in my play that I can improve on. In The Resistance's case I would need to get better at lying, and I don't want to improve on that.  Not to mention that I really dislike discovering that I've been lied to.

As the only time the resistance members have won in our playgroup have been when I've been a spy I can pretty much conclude that having me on your team is of no help, doesn't matter which side.

Decided I never wanted to play again after realizing that regardless of which side I was dealt, resistance or spies, I groaned. 

Bought the 1st edition purely due to the cover art, but I'm not a fan of how dark the cards are. The symbols should be as basic as possible: A big green check mark for yes, a big red 'X' for no.

Most of the optional plot cards are a waste of time, and add nothing to the game but confusion in how they are played.

Oh, and the first round is completely useless as the spies never vote to fail the mission, ever. If three people were to go on it, something interesting might actually be learned, but with only two you may as well just start every game with a default victory point for the resistance and begin round two.

I am really starting to like this game.

RATING: 8
Boiled-down semi co-op/hidden traitor game. It keeps a lot of the paranoia element from Werewolf/Battlestar Galactica. Like Werewolf, it can sometimes suffer from a lack of information in the early rounds; it's important to accumulate information through voting patterns as well as mission success/fails.

I think the lack of player elimination works well.

The only problem is that I would tend to prefer Shadow Hunters for the same player number/weight; it doesn't quite have the paranoia aspect but it's a bit more fun to whack people. Resistance can be played with a standard deck though.

RATING: 7

2nd night, 2 plays, one 8-player and one 10-player: The unbalance with 3 or more spies apparently necessitates using the extra cards.  That actually looks like a lot of fun, BUT makes the game much more complicated for non- or semi-gamers and younger kids.  That was too much with the extended family group tonight, so we modified and played 3 spies in a game of 10 players tonight and the spies still won easily.  The game is less versatile if it is too complicated for a party game with "normal" people.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
50+ plays. Really fun secret identity game of accusation and counter-accusation, with theories being thrown around with gay abandon on who's the baddies and who the goodies. The start player nominates who goes on the next mission, which is then voted on, and who votes yay or nay tells you something. If the majority says nay, the next player nominates a new team for a mission. Once the majority says yay, then the players on the mission vote secretly for success or failure. Any one failure and the mission's a failure. 3 failed missions and the spies win. So the resistance players are desperately trying to work out who they are and get them and only them on the missions. The spies know who each other are, and they're trying to fool the other players into getting a spy or two onto missions so they can shoot the missions down secretly. The game really shines when clever bluff moves happen at the start which set up turmoil later and people are all over the shop. There comes a point where it'll get down to noting hesitations and changes in behaviour in trying to identify the spies. The time value is excellent, and being able to play with 5-10 players is a big plus as not many games do that well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Custom Battlestar Galactica reskin
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Incredibly tense.  I love the fact that the game can last longer than most party games - long enough for the lying to actually mean something.  Lying really becomes conning. If you are one of the good guys, you know someone is lying and you are also afraid people will think you are a traitor and you know how delicate and dangerous politics and influence are.  If you are the spy, you are trying not to sweat bullets or give any hint that you are lying through your teeth for about an hour.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
5-10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
30+ plays - I love resistance because it isn't layered with any of the random nonsense in the werewolf series. At the core of these (resistance) games is figuring out who the 'good guys' are, and who 'bad guys' are - not where random identity tiles were shifted when everyone had their eyes closed. 

It sounds simple, yet nothing else is needed to make the experience excruciatingly difficult. It's pure bluffing, building trust alliances and gaining tells. Just look your best friend in the eye and lie.

This differs a lot from the 'puzzle' of reconstructing the movements of people's id cards and figuring out which team you are actually on (which happens in the werewolf series).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Will_Teach
2 games 1 without roles and 1 with in 70 minutes. 7 players 2 with experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A deduction game played as a group, similar to The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow. You get secretly split into two groups, The Resistance and the Spies and then must try to succeed in three missions if you are part of the Resistance, while the Spies try to sabotage your missions. Depending on the number of players, between 2-5 people get sent on missions and as part of the Resistance you must try to select a group that will all pass the mission since one failure card causes it to fail. Using deduction and discussion, this game is lots of fun, plays in 30 minutes and has a lot of interaction. There are also special powers to help the Resistance, since with more then 5, it is tough to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is a Werewolf-like game with a little more structure.  The group is split secretly into normal players and traitors.  Each turn, the current player must select a number of players to go on a mission; they players on the mission secretly vote for its success or failure.  A single fail vote fails the mission.  A given side wins after a specified number of successes or failures.  Like Werewolf, this game is all about trying to figure out who is a traitor, which often starts with logical arguments but devolves into stupid arguments.  I really don't like arguments of any kind; this game is not for me.

(4 plays)

RATING: 7
這是一個爾虞我詐的遊戲，分成兩個陣營，一邊是間諜，另一邊是反抗軍。間諜的任務是要阻止反抗軍的任務達成。遊戲過程分成三個階段，第一階段是間諜確認彼此身份，第二階段是任務編成，第三是任務執行。所有的贊成與反對票都是秘密進行的，因此遊戲的重點就在於猜出每個人的身分，這時候嘴砲的技巧就很重要啦！可以說是一個兼具心機與嘴砲的遊戲。

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is by far the best game you can buy for a game with some friends that may or may not be "boardgame geeks" 

I played this over Christmas and while it was quite hard to convince people to stop playing trivial pursuit and other layman's games. Once I had got past the (rather easy) explanation of how to play, they literally couldn't stay playing it. We played round after round after round until it was well past time for People to go home. 

It's so much fun to play with friends because all you need to do is lie a bit. A skill most people have naturally and don't have had to have played a lot of games previously to be good at. The concept is super simple to understand and that's what makes it such a good game.

Also, the Dev support on this game is fantastic, I asked a few questions and they were super quick to answer and help me with everything like getting replacement parts.

An amazing game 10 out of 10

RATING: 8
A game that seems light and simple on the outside, but actually is full of strategic manipulations and subtle accusations. I always liked Werewolf, but disliked that the moderator would have to stand out of the game and that player elimination was a part of the game. This solves both of those problems beautifully in a 30 minute game. I love BS Galactica, but this brings out that traitor aspect in just 30 minutes compared to 3 hours, even if it sacrifices some of the terrific tension in that game.

RATING: 9
Probably the best pure social interaction game currently out there. The game is in many ways better than "Werewolf" or "Are you the traitor?" but I will still keep all of them. If the size of the group is between 5 and 10 and they are logically driven people, I would play "The Resistance" every time. "Traitor" can play four, and Werewolf can play more than 10, and in those cases I would probably play those. Also, the latter two can still feel right for very dispair groups. "The Resistance" uses incomplete information for the "good" team to determine who the spies are.

RATING: 8.5
I've played this twice.  I was Imperial both times (9 and 10 players), and it seemed like the Imperials have an advantage.

In the first game, the first 3 people picked were all Rebels, and then a 4th Rebel was added in the second plan.  In the second game, two of the first three people picked were Imperial, and the fourth was also Imperial.  In both games, the Imperials won.

I like the lack of player elimination.  The logic and bluffing involved seems comparable to Werewolf, although the game plays slightly differently (and requires a little bit different thought patterns, at least on the Imperial side).

Update:  Certainly my favorite mafia-style game.  It's been a big hit with almost every group I've tried it on.  It's fun watching a new group of players learn the metagame as they play more and more.

Update:  If you're playing PBF#15 and came here to check out my familiarity with the game, I congratulate you on your thoroughness.  Kudos!

Update:  Oh hi there, PBF#18!

RATING: 5
There's not enough meat to the gameplay to hold my interest. The core of the game is just carefully watching the other players to try to figure out whether they're lying or not. There aren't any game mechanics to add information or mediate the game at all. The only way to make the game interesting or even comprehensible is to develop an elaborate metagame around it with your group, which to me is a deficiency. I much prefer a game like Coup, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, or Sheriff of Nottingham where the bluffing/deduction is part of the game and not the entirety of the game.

My original statement stands, it doesn't play well with 5. 6 and up however it really shines.  I've had intense games with 9 and there was so much chaos that we had to take a break after the game to laugh about how much everyone was getting into their roles.  I find the tokens and mission cards a bit fiddly with very large groups but all in all it's a good game.  The expansions really add to the normal vanilla version of the game.

RATING: 6
Not really a game, more like an lying/deceiving experiment. If you won't talk, the game will simply don't work, especially for more people. You can get some clues, but usually you don't have enough to properly guess, which makes the game random and anti-climatic, really. 

I can understand why some people like this, but I guess you can find better, more engaging party games. I feel like it's a game targeted for younger audience, who likes to shout and argue (pointlessly) a lot.

It feels "wow" when you play for the first time, but after some time, a smart person will simply detect obvious patterns and do a math check every time and simply outsmart others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Just to get it out of the way, while this shares the same basic premise as the core game of BSG, I think there is no way this delivers the same experience as BSG. The decisions in The Resistance are not as intricate and delicate and sometimes, even though you are a human, you will still struggle to make the 'right' decision, which adds nicely to the overall atmosphere of paranoia. The Resistance resembles the bare-bone calculation of BSG's skill checks and the traitor discussions which result thereof but in terms of depth, atmosphere and intensity, this cannot compete with the grand daddy of all traitor games. Still, a neat little game. 

EDIT: Only good without the plot cards and with 5 or 6 players, not more.

EDIT2: I still like this game because of the meta-game but I feel that it is just too hard (too random) to spot the spies, unlike BSG where you have lots (lots!) of time and occurrences that promote the exposure of the traitors. Most of the time, the spies won the game just out of pure chance (4 people on a mission with 6 players, how can you exclude the two spies unless you know exactly who they are ? Not gonna happen)

RATING: N/A
It is getting a little old at this point, but still very enjoyable with the right group. I am looking forward to the expansions, but feel like this game has overstayed its welcome. I still like to bust it out time to time with the right people. With some people though (the introverted/non-confrontational), this game falls very flat. The built in expansion is very lackluster. I have played this game to help make current friendships even tighter, and it worked well. 

I've played with a ridiculous amount of people/groups though, and have seen some very interesting things, ranging from people using basic analysis (ugh playing it in math class) from not saying anything. My friend also told me some cool stories about playing it a camp. I feel like with extroverted/talkative people this game really shines. It does feel very short a lot of times, and with larger groups the deduction is very little. For larger groups, werewolf is recommended. This game plays best with 5-7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
August 2011: This game is very group dependent.

I can't get into the spirit of this game. I play this as silently as possible and let everyone talk their mouths off, which is *not* the way to play the game. I stay silent because it's easier to hide your identity. I get away with it because The Resistance has far more structure and hard information than games like Covert Action or Werewolf.

Still, with the right group, it's fun to watch players uselessly accuse each other.

Down from 6 to 5.

2011-04-17 After several plays of this, it's dropping from 8 to 6. This game is full of pointless arguing about very imperfect information. I personally don't have much patience for this kind of interaction.

At least the game is short.

2010-12-23 Fixes every single problem that Werewolf has:

* No player elimination
* No need for a moderator
* Very short playing time
* You only do the stupid eye-closing thing once

One BGG commenter mentioned that the spies should not know who they are. This breaks the game; Because the resistance has zero incentive to lie (i.e. to make a mission fail), the spies need the advantage of knowing who they are so they can more strategically choose which players can go on a mission.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
10 (expand to 12) players, hidden role teams
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love - absolutely love - this game.  Whether you have five players or ten, it's hard to think of a better "discussion" game.  Werewolf is good, but has two obvious drawbacks - the need for a moderator, and the player elimination (it truly sucks to be killed in the very first night of a long game).  Resistance avoids both problems *and* adds in the voting mechanism so that players are presented with useable information about who might be what.

Balance-wise, playing without the plot cards gives a bias to the spies.  I've played over 20 times without the plot cards and the resistance has won only once or twice.  With the plot cards, the balance swings in favour of the resistance.

But you know what?  Balance issues really don't matter.  This game is all about staring at the person opposite you and convincing them that you are loyal, before turning to your left-hand neighbour and telling them that they are a no-good traitor who couldn't lie straight in bed.  I can't think of a better way to spend 30 minutes with a group of 5-10 friends.

[edit - 4 months later] Did I really rate this game a ten?  I was wrong - it clearly deserves an eleven.  Yes, I know the rating scale you use only goes up to ten, but mine goes to eleven.  Which is higher, obviously.

The only time I'd ever turn down a game of this is if it's past 2am and I've already played four games of The Resistance since midnight.

RATING: 9
Players: 5-10
Time: 30 minutes

A deduction and bluffing game that has the secret roles of Bang!, but minus the hand management, various special cards, and player elimination. The players are members of the Resistance, a rebel group attempting to overthrow a totalitarian regime. However, spies have infiltrated the ranks. The Resistance wins by successfully completing 3 of 5 missions. If any spies assigned to the mission team, however, they may secretely sabotage the mission, endangering the chances of success for the Resistance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.4
Clever little card game. It is not, as it first appears and is usually introduced a co-operative game with a traitor mechanic. It is in fact a game with two teams (the identities of one being hidden from the other).
The rebel team want to succeed missions, the traitors want them to fail. Each round a different mission leader picks a team from the players. All the players vote if they want the team to go on the mission. If they do then all the people on the mission secretly choose pass or fail. One fail dooms the mission.
The rebels must learn who the traitors are and use their superior numbers to keep them from leading or participating in missions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Best hidden role-game!
This game is extremely and even deceptively simple.
Assign leader, he/she hands out mission cards, the group votes yes/no for the mission and if yes, they put down cards approving or disapproving the mission.
So much more is going on in these games though. Mindgames, screwing each other over, accusing one another etc. etc. This game will bring out the worst in your group and can really suck the life out of you.
What an awesome game!

Update: I absolutely adore this game and have the most memorable games of this one, making it my current favourite game to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is not the kind of game which I would ever choose to pick up, but I have played it once, at the UK Games Expo in 2012. It's basically a Werewolf variant with a deck of cards - OK as an end-of-the-evening filler, but why it's a top 100 game I have no idea. If one of my group bought it and wanted to play I'd be happy to, but I have no desire to spend my own money on this game.

RATING: 6
Simple rules, fast playtime and engaging gameplay. As part of the Resistance, you are trying to figure out who the spies are while trying to convince the other players that you are trustworthy. As a spy, you want to sabotage the missions without giving too much information away. Very paranoid!

9 plays in 2 different occasions. 5-8 players. Spies are 5-4. Players ranging from age 8 to 50's. Pretty awesome. We have not used the expansion yet. 

10th play was with a third group of people, 8 players, they did not seem very impressed. 7 Wonders went better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
Pros:
- Persuasion, alliances, subterfuge
- Easy to learn/teach
- Fast setup
- Can be a super rowdy game

Cons:
- You will sometimes need to lie to a person's face and convince them that you are not a spy if you are one.  This can hurt some friendships and create trust issues if you have members in your group that hold grudges or cannot separate life and game.  Be cautious who you choose to play this with.  If you like subterfuge but you have some people who might not do so well with the verbal lying, try Coup instead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Similar to Werewolf or Mafia, this ~15-30min card game is best with 7 players. More than that, and there are too many people to keep track of. Less than that, and it's less of diverse mix of people. It definitely still works at any of 5-10, however. Unlike Mafia, where you have completely no idea who anyone else is (if you are innocent), Resistance offers limited information through cards and helps narrow down suspects. Naturally, spies can use this limited information to their advantage. The barebones of this game is all about bluffing, but those who like to deduce can also take something away from this game. Resistance also does not have player elimination -- where as Mafia if you died, you were out until the next round. This game differs from other "hidden roles" games such as Battlestar Galactica, Bang!, SanGuoSha, Panic Station in that there is less focus on game mechanics and more on bluffing and persuasion. Where in those games, you speak with your cards or your moves (and try to justify why you made those moves), in the Resistance, it's all about reading other people. I have played this game countless times. The game excels when you are playing with different people, although playing with the same group is also fun as you never know who will be the spies next round!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Unless someone is being very sneaky it becomes obvious who is who after a few rounds and the longer the game goes on the less chance the resistance has. So, the resistance is forced to go hard early - even though this exacerbates that problem. It seems to come down in the end to who was lucky enough to choose who with their special cards.

On the other hand, if you're playing with someone who revels in being a bit sneaky then the game can shine. Great when playing with large groups and with people who like to accuse and deny till they're blue in the face. I've come to enjoy it more after a few more plays and was lucky enough to play three times in one evening to nail the quirks to my brain. One of the few games around that plays well with more than six players.

A note here about Indie Boards and Cards. I'm very impressed with them. They know how to produce a fine game. Components are excellent for the price. Box size is spot on. Kickstarter campaigns are very well organised. This is a great package to go with their other games where they've demonstrated the same quality. You are doing a fine job! Keep them coming.

It is very hard for the rebels to win, but the game is not about balance, it is about the atmosphere and tension it creates, in which nobody trusts in nobody.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I've been hearing rave reviews about this game for years now from both friends and the internet alike but I remained skeptical as these party deduction games (i.e. [b]Bang![/b], [b]Shadow Warriors[/b], [b]Ultimate Werewolf[/b], etc.) always seem to be ultimately lacking in some manner (player elimination, length of play is too long, etc.)...

Wow, this game has lived up to the hype. 

After playing one round of [b]The Resistance[/b], it became clear that we finally have a party deduction game that has addressed all the problems with the genre allowing it to become the definitive, iconic game of this type.

My highest recommendation. Essential for everyone's collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
@Sopron
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The essence of Mafia/Werewolf formalized and bottled. Shorter play time (20-30 minutes), no player elimination (and more importantly, no elimination of any strategic options you have), and the availability of actual information to base deductions off, all make The Resistance a far superior game.

Having voting results and mission results complements the social aspect, which isn't hurt at all by the game rules.

2 Plot Cards a turn actually dilutes the elegance a bit for large groups (since you have to read cards and keep track of each person's abilities), but that's a credit to how strategically empowering the few rules are. And seems like you do have to throw out a wild guess for the last mission most of the time, but that's still an improvement over having no concrete information in Mafia/Werewolf. And it's an homage of sorts, since you might just have to use the social aspects (arguments, tells) instead of logic to nail the last Spy.

Experience, like Mafia, really depends on how well you know the players, and how boisterous they are. Hence, I'm selective about if/when I play this.

4+1

If you're going to get Resistance, get Avalon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The Resistance --

See "The Resistance Gets More Organized" on BGN
Submitted by W. Eric Martin on Sun, 2010-07-25 04:19 

    "The Resistance is a very intense social deduction game for 5-10 players. While it shares similiarities with games like Werewolf, Mafia and even Battlestar Galactica it has many very unique features such as a quick 30-minute play time, no moderator required and no player elimination.

    "Set in the near future, The Resistance pits a small group of resistance fighters against a powerful and corrupt government. The resistance has launched a series of bold and daring missions to bring the governement to its knees. Unfortunately spies have infiltrated the resistance ranks, ready to sabotage the carefully crafted plans. Even a single spy can take down a resistance mission team, choose your teams carefully or forever lose your chance for freedom.

    "Included in this release is a full expansion; "The Plot Thickens" is 15 additional action cards that increase the pressure and pacing of the game, and requires the spies to be even more deceitful if they are to achieve victory."

Don't miss correcting the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/5602071#5602071]misprint[/url] in the rules about the number of Plot cards to use.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
One play (of 3 games), just base game.

This definitely works great and I'm yet another member of "Resistance is better than BSG club". Looks like somebody cut all the fat and meat and intestines and wherever could possibly be cut away from BSG and leave just a bare skeleton. However, it's this skeleton which facilitates all the interaction and interaction is what I'm searching for in traitor genre anyhow. If there is a minus to this game is that it actually is too skinny - so much intensiveness as this generates in 15-20 minutes of gameplay is hard to withstand for several repeated plays - some more relaxed structure (like in werewolf) would help this game to have more longevity. BUT I'm yet to check the expansion (in the box). For now a great filler.

EDIT: played some more. Lack of narrative arch is a problem - you can make one though. 
BUT - with expansion (the plot thickens) the game goes in overanalitical mode and kills and theme. Essentially it becomes a deduction game and I'm not fond of that. I prefer base game, though spies are too strong in that one. Will try some more with different groups to make the final verdict. Personally I'd prefer some narrative, making game loner by killing narrative and creating AP with needless decisions (plot cards) is not what I'm after. Resistance, I love you better when you don't try too much to make an impression - keep it simple!

Great game that invokes conversation and not giving yourself away by being quiet or too talkative.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
#15 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

I still remember when I first heard about The Resistance, back in early 2013. I grew up playing lots of Mafia, so I was a big fan of social deduction (although I don't believe I knew this term at the time). Resistance was pitched to me as similar to Mafia, but much shorter and there is no player elimination. I purchased the game immediately and began searching for a group to play with. I looooooooooved it. Absolutely could not get enough of it. My enthusiasm for it has since squelched a little bit as I've found a couple other social deduction games I enjoy more. But anytime we get a solid group of 7 or so and someone suggests playing The Resistance, I'm probably on board. I love the amount of paranoia it creates. I like playing the spy and trying to trick everyone just as much as I like being the noble rebel who is just trying to figure things out. Top notch game! Creates one of the most interesting atmospheres I've seen for a game that plays in 20 minutes or less. 

Acquired: February 2013 - Amazon

RATING: 7

This is particularly great because I find this is the most clumsy part of the game and, with a lot of new people, is easy for people to mess up, which leads to having to deal out roles all over again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Much more enjoyable variation on the Werewolf/Mafia theme. Players are not left to rely exclusively on blind accusations and psychology, as in Werewolf. The voting mechanism and the plot cards allow for deduction. Psychology and bluffing is still an important part of the game though.

Players are not eliminated during the game, and the group does not need to be as big as in Werewolf. This increases the number of occasions where you can actually play this game.

RATING: 8
Played a few games with pals.  Was a big success with instantly wanting to play again.  We played 9 though and didn't do the 2 fails for the end game.  It did seem that spies had it to easy, so I was pleased to note that we played wrong on missions 4 and 5.  

Since I sometimes have game nights with people less into heavy games and often with too many for a lot of the other good games I have a feeling I will get to play this one a lot.

Update: Putting this at an 8 after latest round.  Played with a completely different group (6 players) and it went even better.  First game people got their feet wet and all missions just got approved, but by 2nd game more talking and voting down missions and blind accusations and just FUN FUN FUN.  Easily deserves an 8 even though it is "just a party game".  Still have yet to use the expansion cards, probably will wait a bit though.

RATING: N/A
3 copies
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game always gets my group tense and excited. There's a lot of yelling, arguing, pleading, and laughing. Sometimes we actually skip the game because it is really emotionally exhausting but we love it.

A negative: the game definitely leans towards a Spies advantage with more players and the Inquisitor role doesn't really give the Resistance an advantage. It pretty much just increases the possible plays and mind-fucking in the game but typically only helps out the team that starts out with it.

Some things to keep in mind: everyone really has to make sure cards/tokens stay face down until appropriate times. Make sure nothing is being accidentally flipped over. We have a player who has a habit of turning cards face up when he gathers cards to shuffle... it has lead to a lot of accidental team reveals. In earlier missions with few starting cards (2-3) we'll typically have a person next to the leader shuffle the cards under the table before the leader shuffles again and does the reveal. If we don't it becomes too easy for people to visually track who dropped which card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[2011-12-17]
Az ősrégi Maffia vagy Vérfarkasos néven híressé vált játék újragondolása a Resistance. A játékosok közül az egyik csoport a jó a másik a rossz oldalt képviseli. Két csavarral és egy újabb játékmóddal egészítették ki a készítők a régi játékot. Először is van egy vezető, aki megpróbál megadott számú csapatot szervezni. Kioszt csapattagsági kártyát és az összes játékos megszavazza egyetért-e a létrejövő csapattal, ha nem továbbadódik a vezetői jog és az új vezető próbálkozik ezzel ismét meg. Ha sikerült létrejönnie a csapatank, akkor már csak annyi dolguk van, hogy azonosan szavaznak a misszió sikeréért. Ha ez megvan akkor egy pontot kapnak a jók, ha nincs, akkor a rosszak. Illetve úgy kaphatnak még a rosszak pontot, ha egyik vezetőnek sem sikerülne csapatot szerveznie, de erre nagyon kicsi az esély véleményem szerint. A játékot még plusz kártyák bonyolíthatják meg. 3 nyert pontig megy a játék. Semmi extra, bármikor elővehető, gyors könnyed játék. Nagy társaságokba ideális pihentetésnek. A kivitelezés teljesen rendben van.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Plays quick and I love deception as part of a larger game, but there isn't much game here and I think it gets its pseudo replay value from addictive high feelings that occur during each and every game (which differ depending on what team you're on). So it's replayable, but repeat games don't seem to reveal additional depth (honing your deception isn't as intersting to me here as in something like BSG or Secret Hitler since you have so many more tools to work with in those games; the plot cards actually seem overwrought to me)

Just feels like it boils down to a social experience rather than a deeper competition. Which is fine if the occasion is in fact that, but this is not a game night game for me. 

[hr]Reevaluated this now that I've realized that this really is a superior filler to much of the other game night stuff. It is a good filler. But it's not as good as Secret Hitler and I will continue to cringe when people suggest it obsoletes Battlestar Galactica.

[b]I'd Rather Play: Secret Hitler[/b]

RATING: 9.5
(2010-10-04) A great hidden-faction/betrayal game, pared down to its simplest possible implementation. Replayability is not great, but this may be improved somewhat by the boxed version's special cards, which I haven't gotten yet. It's very interesting to see the McCarthy-ish accusations come out as people try to figure out who's on which side.

(2013-09-21) Three years on, finally got around to revising my rating of this upward. Still a fantastic game, now with lots of variants to make it work better with different player counts and different experience levels. If you're at all open to the idea of a hidden faction bluffing and betrayal game, this is the one you want.

I havent played with any advanced rules yet - maybe this makes the game more interesting?

RATING: 7
The Resistance takes the traitor mechanic found in other games, but strips it to its core. What's left is a great 30-minute blast filled with player interaction and actual deduction. It drops the convoluted relusets and player elimination. It's portable, which is perfect for this kind of party game. The production values are top notch.
The included, optional expansion is the way to play, though. The added plot cards were our main source of information and deduction in the games I've played so far.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great social game with the feel of Werewolf/Mafia, minus player elimination and the need for a moderator. It's Battlestar Galactica distilled, done in 15 minutes. However, it's hard for the resistance to win, unless either: 1) they're all thinking logically, or 2) they can reliably identify the spies from "tells." That's not a knock against the game, not exactly, but worth noting.

The plot cards make the game worse, so I always play without them. As a result, Avalon is the better buy, as you can use it to play the basic game or not, depending on the crowd. Alternatively, there are two admittedly overpriced expansions to do what Avalon does and more.

RATING: 8.5
Though it's starting to get a little stale for me, this is largely because I just can't seem to get the chance to be a spy.  I love being the bad guy!

Definitely my favourite hidden role, traitor-style "party" game.  Far superior to more complex fare such as Shadow Hunters or Shadows Over Camelot, yet much deeper than Werewolves without being much more complicated.

I do wish the game was less ostentatiously produced, however -- seems pretty common with Kickstarter and Indie games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Distills the essence of BSG without all the chrome into a MUCH shorter game.  I still prefer Werewolf for games of this genre (not my favorite). but it's still a fun little game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Hidden role games at their purest are crappy in my opinion.  There's no real gameplay and unless you have players who are trained interrogators or absolutely awful liars these kinds of games really just boil down to random finger-pointing.  I like that in Werewolf you can add characters with special abilities to add more of this gameplay to the game and I really like Bang! because at the same time you're playing the guessing game you're also playing a card dueling game that can be very telling or give you the opportunity to bluff very well.  I don't see any of that in The Resistance.

The Resistance SHOULD BE better than basic Werewolf finger-pointing because you can analyze why certain people were chosen for a mission and how many people made it fail, etc. but people can make incredibly illogical choices that make it impossible to intelligently guess who the spies are.  This presents an incredible flaw in the game that doesn't make it any better than a game of basic Werewolf.  AKA boring, senseless, yelling at each other.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
A variant of the popular Mafia/ Werewolf games. This game is less open ended as compared to Mafia/ Werewolf as there is a larger deduction aspect to it.

In the first "voting" round in Mafia/ Werewolf, most players do not have any real information to work with and for some groups of players, it is hard to get the conversation going.

The Resistance on the other hand guarantees the group that they have information to work with - the first mission you go on provides a great ice-breaker to start the conversation going - Mafia/ Werewolf does not have this luxury.

Due to the structure of The Resistance, the game does tend to end MUCH earlier than Mafia/ Werewolf. You can easily finish games under 30 minutes constantly.

Highly recommended if your group likes Mafia or Werewolf.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
After my only mediocre experience with BS Galactica I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this game. It is more to the point, faster and therefor a lot more fun in my opinion. It still makes you yell "You are a spy" at each other, if that is not your thing stay away. But truth to be told, I thought this type of game was not my thing and I had so much fun. It is true, I would say it is a board game only in the loosest sense but it is more than a party gag, it makes you think you can calculate the options logically but maybe you are only paranoid?
Played 4 times (2 times without, 2 times with plot cards) in a varying range from 8 to 10 players, works great for bigger groups. Those who like "different" game experiences should not hesitate.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good party game for 6 or more. Never played with more than 5-6 players.  Don't know if it would get too chaotic or not with say 10 players.  Non-gamers seem to like it as the whole concept is so original and new to them and it's a nice tight smooth running game. Nobody gets eliminated and no need for an independent player to run and referee the game as I've heard Werewolf does?

A couple non-gamers felt that when they were not the spies they felt like their path was boring and all the voting would pretty much be monotonous as they always just sit and wait to "succeed" the mission.

When they were not spiess they should really be focusing studying others and how they vote and try to help their team but filtering out the spies but the game I guess didn't pull them in enough to keep their attention span that long.

For me, I found that in the end it "felt" as if no matter what logic you had based on your friends reactions, voting, deduction of any sort could always be explained away and therefore you never really could "strategically" deduce anything. If that were the case then really it all came down to too much luck.

I agree that the point of the game is in playing the game with people who can get into it and just enjoying the experience.

I would prefer a similar game where there would be some sort of component of true deduction and strategy involved.

When playing the first few times, for me it felt like there was "perceived" feeling that maybe you had figured a spy out because of they way the acted, or voted but in the end it was really a toss up with your guess, so it felt like little to no strategy which is not as appealing to me.

Am looking into Coup the reprint to see if it's a slightly more "strategic" version of Resistance and maybe an even better game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A year ago, The Resistance was one of my favourite games.

The economy of components was impressive - how could you fit so much gameplay into one box?

I played it with various gaming groups, and it went down well with the more hardcore gamers. When I cracked it out with the family though, it went down like a lead balloon, even though similar titles like Coup went down amazingly well.

And that's my main issue with the Resistance - Coup is better in most situations. It still has the bluffing aspect, but has more structure which makes it more accessible. You can also play it with fewer players.

I still play the Resistance, but where it was once a gaming staple, now we treat it like a fine wine. We bring it out on occasion for people who'll appreciate it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I vote in favour of this game.  It is a very clever take on the "hidden roles" genre, and quite frankly, kicks Werewolf's ass.  For me, it's quite comparable to "Shadow Hunters", which is high praise indeed.  When comparing the two, I would say that "The Resistance" is a little more portable, a little simpler, can play with a slightly larger group (5-10, verses an optimal number of 5-8 for "Shadow Hunters"), and is just as fun.  I can't really find any fault with the card artwork, nor can I say that it's particularly interesting (the symbolism is basic but functional).  This one is a definite keeper - mission accomplished!  Game design: 4/5  Personal enjoyment: 4/5  Total: 8/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
My deduction game for groups 5 to 8. The rules seem to new player more confusing then in werewolf, often they dont know what to do and just find it random, but with more rounds they realize the mechanics and interactions. I like the point of no player elimination.

RATING: 9
Screams of "LIAR!", "SPY", "DON'T PICK HIM", mixed with cackles of laughter and groans of anguish as a spy is voted onto the last, critical mission.  This game is quick, amazing fun, and one to bring out the best in any group. The mechanics of the game are really simple, and work well to build the tension and mistrust as the rounds progress.  This is a must have for any gaming group.

RATING: 7
Improved version of Werewolf; not my sort of game so can't see choosing it over something with exciting cube-pushing, but fun, and I'm interested in getting a copy to play with non-gamer friends.

Edit: after a few more plays I'm getting pretty tired of it. I'm interested in trying with the plot cards; without them, unless the spies do something obviously silly then it's more or less impossible to actually deduce anything. An example from yesterday: various people saying they knew X or Y, when all we actually knew for certain was that one of the seven people who had been on missions so far was a spy -- ultimately it turned out to be two of them (and one more), one of whom was never under suspicion. Maybe you're lucky enough to stumble on a winning combination, maybe not.

I am also somewhat alarmed by how good so many people are at lying. :zombie:

RATING: 5

 Edit

 This was a good thing. Getting old now. The game pretends that there are ways of logically deducing who the traitors are but in actual fact, unless someone cocks up, there is no way to do it. This leads to endless arguments, in which never ending circles of logic are repeated forever. I'd rather play werewolf, which is at least honest about the complete randomness of its accusations.

 Resistance can still be fun, particularly with non-board gamers, but I would usually rather play something else.

RATING: 8
Amazing game that is tons of fun for non-gamers to hardcore gamers. The only problem I have with the game is that it seems tilted towards the Spies and I wish there was more "information" available (like being able to see people's roles or something). The variants add a bit of fun, but only Merlin + Assassin seems to be one that we keep coming back to. Another problem is it really is only amazing at 7 players exactly. It is decent at 6 and 8, but I have to average out the score between those number of players.

EDIT: Using the "Trapper Keeper Module" or whatever it is called combined with Merlin really pushes this game above others. Fast, fun, and has a decent amount of information in that situation.

If played with 7 people who know what they are doing and those two variants, I'd give the game a solid 8.5 to a 9.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun multi-player deduction game. The majority of players assume the roles of resistance members, whilst a minority (known only to each other) are spies. The resistance have to form teams to complete missions, and these are voted on by all players. Once the team has been formed each member secretly determines whether the mission is a success or failure. The spies have a dilemma on whether to attempt to protect their identity by passing a mission (which will make victory more difficult for themselves) or to fail it thereby increasing the chance of being exposed and therefore left off future missions. The resistance however are continually guessing who the spies may be in order to ensure that the missions are successful. This game is a lot of fun with accusations and denials being thrown around left, right and centre and it is ideal for situations when there are a lot of players.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A fun game.
I think it tends to be imbalanced in favor of the spies, as they almost always win.
Blind spies is probably too heavy a mod, but there should be a way to limit their power, for example by always only having two spies regardless of the number of players. Knowing each other is a huge advantage, but not knowing each other would be too crippling.
Apart from these considerations, it's a very fun game. Much simpler than the Devil's Castle, which has a lot of layers making it difficult and kinda frustrating to keep track of things. The Resistance is more straightforward but not less challenging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's rather similar to werewolfe, however the big advantage is that you can play with a lot less players, say 6 (is 5 possible?). I sort of like the decision making process better in this case, as you have to choose a team. The roles/abilities are not as complex as werewolfe and they dont really thrill me. I'd rather play werewolfe if we have enuf players. One negative: the production, viz. the voting cards and the other stuff is counter intuitive. What should be a very basic: yes or no vote is confusing with the strange voting tokens as well as the backs. This doesnt affect my rating, and shouldnt effect your game play; just a peeve.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the game that I have spent most time thinking about for a long time now..... The 'game' is all in the social interactions and the components aren't really a huge part of the game. At this point (6/9/13) I remain intrigued by the game and can't figure out a winning strategy. I think this is because thee isn't one! At least I mean that what is required in each game differs so widely that it is not possible to solve the game. Being a spy requires you to lie convincingly and hold your story straight. It's not easy but.... Being resistance requires that you figure out who the spy's are and that is VERY difficult. Little clues may accumulate but in the end there will never be any hard proof and you have to make your best judgement. Paranoia, distrust, deception, back stabbing. Awesome (6/9/13)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
YAIP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If you have ever played Mafia or Werewolf, this game should feel immediately familiar.  It is a social deduction game for 5+ players, where the evil corporations are trying to root out the spies attempting to overthrow the establishment.  This game is unique because unlike Mafia/Werewolf, there is no player elimination.  You live and die as a team and there is never downtime for any players.  The game is excellently thought out and adds in cards that give players special powers that help make the game more interesting.  If you have a large group that needs a game to play, I would recommend this game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played this with the lunch gaming group with just a print-out board and marked poker chips. What fun! There was more aspects in this game than meets the eye, and we played it again the next week.

Played this at Albert's place with Albert, Shaz, Irwin, Richie and Rosalie. Was a Spy and managed to fool Rosalie into thinking that I was Resistance [i]even after the spies were caught out with 2 Sabotage cards[/i]. Classic.

Played this at Convic 2011 and was rather intimidated by some of the other players. In the end, I think my enjoyment of this game depends on who I'm playing with.

RATING: 8
In many ways better than Werewolves of Millers Hollow, but sadly lacks the narrative.  The art fantastic as well as the theme.  You need the right sort of group for this to be a hit which can be kind of a let down.  Still the social experience here is one not to miss.  No player elimination and plenty of dirty tricks to be had, it stands above it's predecessors in the genre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.3
Good for the right players, but I'm just not a fan. It may have been the crowd I played with -- people who grew up unwinding convoluted logic strings in Mafia.  It felt very hard to make any move without either outing myself immediately or forfeiting my actual objective (and thus losing anyway). I just don't have the talent for it. And then there goes an hour. So while the game probably has merit somewhere, I can't even play this game well enough to enjoy failure. (Because in some games, even if you're losing at least it feels like you're doing something, like watching the mechanics interact in interesting ways. But Resistance has no real mechanics; it's just filibustering with a vote at the end.)

Resistance also suffers unusually hard from ornery players, and because of its hidden information and length you often can't determine that someone's just being an ass until you've already wasted an hour. (See all the stories about players who vote "fail" on the Resistance team, never mind the ones that do it intentionally.)

RATING: 8
Fun, quick playing game of trying to suss out which players are the traitors. It is very much like Werewolf, but with some additional structure that I enjoy. The newer Avalon version of game adds in Merlin and Assassin cards, that add special powers. I don't think these are necessary. I appreciate the purity of the original, especially when I'm playing a quick game with a large crowd. I also tend to like the sci-fi theme better than the fantasy theme.

RATING: 9
Received in Math Trade.

As a Spy: Great game! A lot of fun trying to set up scenarios to sabotage the game but at the same time making innocents look guilty. I have great success in correctly identifying my co-conspirators. If players believe me the trust me. If they don't believe, well that is good too!

As a Resistance Player: Great game! A lot of fun trying to figure out who is ruining the game. Watching votes, watching teams being made. I can usually figure it out, the problem is getting people to believe me once I figure it out because I lied to them the last game!!

The best large group game.

==Not for you if==  

Your game group includes people who cannot bluff or lie without being obvious.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm gonna start this with a 7 rating, but I think it could easily go up from there. The resistance was a very pleasant surprise. It's quick, tense, interesting and sometimes pretty funny (as in a recent game where two agents/spies were on three-person mission together and neither played a sabotage card (for fear of having two sabotage cards appear and blowing their cover), allowing the Resistance to win. I love that, unlike Werewolf, you have a bit of real information on which to base decisions (even if it's not enough info or you misinterpret it). Also a huge bonus is that this plays well wtih as few as five people and takes all of 10 minutes to play. Need to play a bit more to see if this holds up to repeated play, but I'm very hopeful.

It's popular enough that I still end up playing it, but I'd almost always be playing something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As social-deduction games go, The Resistance is the best I've played. If you like Mafia and want to put a little more structure to it with very attractive, minimal components, this is your game. This game takes what's great about Mafia and makes it better by replacing the nightly killing with a voting system that allows all players to voice their opinions (and everybody WILL have an opinion) until the very end. More simply put: no player elimination.

I used to play a lot of Shadow Hunters, but now I play this for a more intense social experience.

3/7/2012 -- Now up to 68 plays! I'm increasing my rating to a 9. This game delivers better in its category than any other by a long shot. It creates tension and paranoia better than any other. It is simple, yet deep in its gameplay. I'm often exhaused after playing a couple rounds because it has me on the edge of my seat the entire time. It is kind for social deduction and paranoia in board gaming.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 5
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 5
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 4
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 4


Overall - 5

RATING: 10
1.6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Sadly, lying is tainted with negative connotations in society. Yet there are many valid reasons for doing so and is an important social survival mechanism for humans.

Thankfully, lying (or bluffing, or however you want to term it) is an acceptable part of gaming and is the crux of The Resistance. Sure, you probably can win and only tell the truth, but it's more fun the other way.

The Resistance still is one of the best social games out there. It has given my gaming group many awesome moments that we all enjoy to recollect, and has probably created more of those than any other game I've played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Werewolf/Mafia for 5-10 players. Without player elimination. And faster than 20 minutes.

It's more difficult for the resistance players, but more agonising for the spies which in turn forces them to make mistakes.

Great game, even more so for ad-hoc groups.

Update: No need to rate or play this, when Avalon is available. Still a great game for those without access to Avalon, or in love with the sci-fi setting. The expansions might also rejuvanate this once available.

RATING: 10
This is the best social deduction game I've ever played, by far.  It is a beautiful thing when the mechanics of a game fade away temporarily and the player interactions become the only focus, and that's what this game does perfectly.  Some of my most heated discussions and arguments have taken place while playing this game because it ignites a passion.  You have to be good at reading people to be good at this game, but unlike other social deduction games I've played there is solid overlying logic to rely on as well.  As near to perfection as I can imagine.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[U]Update after 27 plays.[/U]Signaling has taken over the local metagame, and for me a game of passing secret hand signals and kicks rather than deduction is making it less fun. Also, too much of the in-game talk is getting into side conversations on how to play and post-game analytics are getting less focussed on the event and about the metagame. Dropped the rating, it's just turned into a big argument & it grew hard to separate some of the dynamics that grew over time from the game itself. But that said it's lovely too, I've had astounding moments of surprise.

*
[u]Original comment & through most of the plays:[/u]
So many priceless & shocking moments have come from playing this; truly memorable. This game draws out personalities & has the most exquisite & hilarious meta-game. I especially recommend it as a topper after a day's gaming; it thrives on releasing all that compressed angst from playing T&E or Twilight Struggle. 

That logic & evidence is filtered & bent by emotion is well modeled. The beauty & flaws of all our personalities get out there & that's a good thing. 

The rules & minimal structure are exquisite. Produced with quality & heart by Indie Boards and Cards.

RATING: 6.5
Good:
-Great components
-A ton of interaction
-A social game for gamers
-Plays up to 10 well (best with 8)

Bad:
-Easily dominated by certain personalities
-Players can be too logical and intimidate/turn off other players
-Games can mirror each other too often
-Quite players can disappear

Overall:
I'm not sure where this one fits in.  It's a little too much pretending for non-gamers and not great with hardcore gamers; however, if you have an open-minded group, this is a blast.

RATING: 7.5
Kickstarter
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A werewolf/mafia inspired social deduction game. The biggest improvement to this game is the abolishing of player elimination during the five rounds of game play. Instead of direct group accusation and subsequent elimination of one player in the game, players vote to approve or reject members that participate in missions which will determine the direct outcome of each mission. Based on the open votes cast for approval or rejection of mission members and the subsequent success or failure of the mission, certain deductions can be made to tease out who the rebels are in the group. Clearly, from a Euro stand point, no player elimination is good for the game. However, players must be invested in the game. If there are rogue players in the group that make illogical choices or do not play with the right spirit of the game, this game quickly gets broken and completely unplayable. Hit or miss depending on group.

11/08/2014: Truth is there needs to be a range for ratings for this game. In certain groups with a mix of strangers, newbies and casual gamers, this game is a 4. With close friends, family or other gamers in a group, this game can be a 9. It really all depends. So, a 7 is a fair rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
While at first I felt a bit let down by the fact that, despite a larger element of logical deduction, there was still a high level of uncertainty (a la Werewolf), The Resistance has really grown on me. 

The logic element provides something to latch on to (even more so with the Plot cards), and really makes the choices interesting for the Spies. It seems to play better with fewer players (less downtime), and still manages to be tense throughout (unless you have some sucky spies).

RATING: 2

We lost.

RATING: 7
This definitely deserved kudos for taking a game with so many flaws (Mafia) and removing a lot of them (player elimination, 400-year long games), condensing the best of the paranoia together.

Like any games of the genre, though, you need committed people to make this game great-- it flops if people don't really get what's going on.

Still, after a few more plays, I really also like that it's super easy to explain. Even though BSG still remains dear to my heart, Resistance actually has a chance to hit the table more than once a year...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pros: social deduction with bluffing mechanic, no player elimination like most other games like it, quick playtime

Cons: limited strategic & tactical options

I'm not normally a fan of social deduction games, but did enjoy this one. When compared to something like One Night Ultimate Werewolf, there is a lot less pressure to be a perfect liar/actor, for whatever reason. The game is short and sweet so it's easy to play multiple rounds, and it's great that there's no player elimination.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Party-game style secret identity/traitor game in the same vein as Werewolf, however no player actually gets eliminated. The only minor gripe is that the multiple voting & mission pass/fail cards can cause some confusion for non-gamers as they learn the game. While Werewolf may be a better overall game due to its simpler base rules, The Resistance is the better game in the 8-10 player range.

RATING: 7.5
The Resistance is a lively game of deduction. There are just enough known factors to spark rational discussion and accusations, while there are sufficient unknowns to usually prevent an ironclad deduction, keeping the game tense to the finish.

This game is loads of fun BUT is very group dependent. Younger players may struggle to grasp the game and 1 or 2 players that don't "get it" can really water down the fun. The good news is that it usually only takes 1 game (or even part of a game) to grasp how things work.

RATING: 6
It's hard for me to play hidden role games well when I'm selected as a traitor, because it's hard for me to lie, and if I win, some part of me thinks that those people I deceived will never trust me completely again.  The Resistance is a nice take on the concept of Werewolf, and the hardcore Werewolf players are saying that this game actually improves on it somewhat.  For me, though, I get that same feeling of being anxious whenever I play, and it's hard for me to see much difference in the games.  The idea of the game is appealing, but the execution makes my blood pressure go up, and the doctor told me to avoid anything that does that.

2 plays: 5 players
1 play: 7 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The Empire must fall. Our mission must succeed. By destroying their key bases, we will shatter Imperial strength and liberate our people. Yet spies have infiltrated our ranks, ready for sabotage. We must unmask them. In five nights we reshape destiny or die trying. We are the Resistance!
\13\\13\
The Resistance is a party game of social deduction. It is designed for five to ten players, lasts about 30 minutes, and has no player elimination. The Resistance is inspired by Mafia/Werewolf, yet it is unique in its core mechanics which increase the resources for informed decisions, intensify player interaction, and eliminate player elimination.
\13\\13\
Players are either Resistance Operatives or Imperial Spies. For three to five rounds, they must depend on each other to carry out missions against the Empire. At the same time, they must try to deduce the other players’ identities and gain their trust. Each round begins with discussion. When ready, the Leader entrusts sets of Plans to a certain number of players. Everyone votes on whether or not to approve the assignment. Once an assignment passes, the chosen players secretly decide to Support or Sabotage the mission. Based on the results, the mission succeeds (Resistance win) or fails (Empire win). When a team wins three missions, they have won the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Modernized Werewolf. Evil team knows each other and tries to make missions fail. Good guys try to win by succeeding missions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I see this one being really fun if you are very vocal and enjoy debating, but it could be intimidating if you are not.  It did feel very thematic to me, though.  My heart was pounding when I was the spy, and I felt very guilty about lying to the members of the Resistance about my loyalty.  I really liked that there wasn't player elimination, too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The Resistance is a social deduction game, like Werewolf, but designed for far smaller groups. It only works with a loud and rambunctious crowd, as blindly (at least initially) accusing people of being a spy is the entirety of game play. Everything is abstract, you basically pick a few people to go on a mission and then they vote to be successful or to sabotage it. Essentially, it's nothing more than the Crisis phase from Battlestar Galactica. The lack of backstory for The Resistance's mission phase means that the immersion level is far lower and less satisfying than BSG, but the rules overhead and start up time is also significantly smaller. Admittedly, the best parts of BSG are the Cylon accusations, so focusing a game completely on that is a bit of a master stroke.

It's not terribly deep, but it's fun and extremely portable, (and cheap) so I think it has a place in almost any collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Adrian
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Finally got it, have yet to play it but I assume it's going to be an instant classic!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was a big disappointment for me; even though I liked the game, I was really hoping for "Battlestar Galactica in 20 minutes!", which this is not. It's more like a streamlined Werewolf, which is not a bad thing, but it shares the biggest problem I have with that game, which is that it's pretty much all about the personalities of the players. To me, BSG's biggest innovation on the concept (and the reason it's one of my favorite games) is the way in which the skill checks work. As a cylon, you can sabotage the check by only putting in a low value "good" card, and even if you put in a negative card, the destiny deck shields you slightly. In The Resistance, a sabotage card narrows it down pretty well, and if you bluff by playing positive cards at the beginning, it's a risky proposition since you don't know if you'll be selected again. Again, it's not a bad game, but I was really hoping to have something that I could play that captured the same feel as BSG in 10% of the time, but this is instead an improved, focused version of Werewolf that's more true to the roots of the game. In other words, something I'll play if others want to, but nothing I'll go out of my way to track down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Improved Werewolf? Overall, I think so. No elimination is fantastic, and the two-staged mission system is good.

But the theme is not remotely as appealing as Werewolf, and I miss the rule-breaking roles. The action cards are not as good as hoped for.
