=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is so awesome.  You're given enough information to perform some quite complex deductive reasoning, but not enough to completely solve the problem.  I'm a logic guy and tend to argue vociferously for that angle, but so far the intuition and people-reading folks have been just as (if not more) accurate.  So there's still plenty of room for that.

Our group loved Werewolf, but I can't see us ever going back.  This game is Werewolf perfected.  The Resistance is more condensed and constrained than Werewolf, but our games actually end up taking longer because of all the protracted arguing, counter-arguing, and whatnot.  That's the fun part, of course.

Both being a spy and a resistance member are a ton of fun.  It's fun to puzzle through the information as a resistance member, and of course fun to deceive as a spy.

We've given the optional plot cards a few whirls, but they didn't take.  Straight up, this game is a pitch-perfect blend of deduction, people reading, and vein-popping arguments.  No need to jazz it up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A game of social deductio with no player elimination. you are either Resistance Operatives or Imperial Spies. For three to five rounds, you must depend on each other to carry out missions against the Empire. At the same time, you must try to deduce the other players identities and gain their trust. Each turn you must put together a team, that you trust, to go on a mission. If you are a spy you must blend in and throw off suspession, if you are resistance, you must find the spies before it is too late.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is great fun.  First off, it is very approachable.  The theme isn't so specific that it will turn away non-gamers.  Second, it is easy to learn and teach.  Third, it can play up to 10 players, which makes the game great in party situations.  Fourth, it is quick.  That makes it great when you have enough players and you are looking for a game that won't take you hours.  You can introduce this game to new people easily and there is a good chance that it will be a hit.  One concern is that it does require at least 5 players, and sometimes that is not the best number in gaming groups.  But if you have the players, give this one a shot.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This can be a great party game, but in my experience you have to have a good balance of personalities. Its no fun if everyone is just quiet, but if too many people are playing up the drama it can be overwhelming. The game is a hidden role game where players select different teams to complete missions and based on the outcome of those missions players need to determine who the spies are. If you have the right group it is a lot of fun with, all of the accusations. "I'm not the spy!" "That's exactly what a spy would say!" "...?"

RATING: 9.6

8.5 after 10 plays
--
Raised the rating to 9+ after 20 plays. A game I rarely would decline to play. My most memorable, enjoyable, loudest and funniest gaming moments has come with this game. Prefer this game a lot over Avalon. 
-- 
After 40+ plays it now has reached a 9.6 rating. The game is a masterpiece. The rogue-cards in the expansion also helps a little with gameplay at some player-numbers that needed some extra depth. 
The only complain about the game is that a round can be ruined if a new player joins that don´t understand the game at all. Also, the game can be a bit dull if the players doesnt interact and try to play the game as it is intended to.

RATING: 7
We played this a few times during the Thanksgiving holiday and really enjoyed it. It was fun trying to deduce who the spies were, and we discovered some people were very good at deceit. The key is a strong poker face, and either not saying anything, or saying just the right thing at the right time. We had a younger player who didn't quite understand the nuances, and ruined it because he didn't know why he should vote a certain way. But other than that, it was a solid game that would probably be more fun with the larger number of players.

RATING: 7.5
Uitstekend psychologisch spel waarin de spelers in twee kampen worden opgedeeld.

De spelers zijn of spion of verzetsstrijder. Door missies uit te voeren en deze al dan niet te laten lukken moeten de verzetsstrijders op het spoor van de spionnen zetten. Leuk is dat iedereen moet stemmen op ieder voorstel dat wordt gedaan over welke spelers de missie gaan uitvoeren.

Uitstekend voor een grotere groep mensen.

RATING: 7
I hate to use a deductive proof to explain why I'll never play this game again, but here goes:

[i]Premise A[/i]: I have to be at the point where I'm burnt out and delirious from playing "normal" games before I'm willing to play a party game.

[i]Premise B[/i]: The Resistance is a party game that requires focused mental activity to be satisfying.

[i]Conclusion[/i]: Premises A and B are mutually exclusive, so The Resistance has deduced itself right into the trash heap.

[i]Update:[/i]

Much better the second time, and it even plays well with five.  It's nice when games improve with time, which can be a rarity these days.

Not really a party game, either, so I'll cut out my tongue and ask for forgiveness.

RATING: 6.5
While I still stand by my original statement in the beginning of 2014 that, "This is a game that I think everyone should have in their collection", it hasn't come to the table as much as I originally thought/hoped. While it's a ton of fun with the right group of people and something that I'd enjoy playing at any gathering, you really do need to have the "right" group of people to play this game.

My gaming group tends to focus on my strategic games and/or ones that can be played with 3-4 people. With the Resistance, you really need at least 5 and probably more like 7 or 8 to really have a lot of fun. The problem is, the people that I thought this would most appeal to (eg., my non-gaming friends) have never really warmed up to it... or games in general. As such, it's just sit on my shelf. It's something that I'll probably hold on to though as you never know when the right opportunity will arise to play it. Luckily it's such a small box...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

I've played it about 15 times now, and 1 of my friends who's played all those 15 times as well, never has been a spy before. So now, each game, everyone assumes he will be a spy next time. So much paranoia... I love it.

Played around 10 games last night (april 7th, 2012) and it was awesome. The guy that never has been a spy before was a few times spy this time. And once again, I was the spy pretty often.

RATING: 6
Fantastic fun! I love this social, paranoia-driven game. It's a perfect filler for 5-10 player groups, and also works equally well as a party game with the right crowd.

It distills the "traitor mechanism" from so many other games, such as Battlestar Galactica, into its bare essentials and a short filler, but still retains the paranoia and other good bits of bluffing, lying, and deceiving your friends. I highly recommend it.

RATING: 7
I usually don't like games with more than 6 players as they tend to drag getting bogged down in all the player decisions.  This game remains fun and light regardless of number and plays quickly for a couple of sessions in an hour if you're in the mood.  I love the traitor mechanic in Shadows over Camelot and BSG... but those are some clunky, dragging animals i feel no need to play again having had a shot at The Resistance!

I really like the base game with odd numbers.  I now always add the Merlin variant with even numbers though to make the Resistance skewed games more interesting.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I like Werewolf (When played as a real party game, with several rooms, and interesting roles), but this is utter and total crap. The lowest possible rating I can give a game that doesn't threaten to kill me.

I've played 5 times (8 people) and it's  an exercise in futility. Best of 5 is much too short to get any sort of information that's reliable, so in the end, it's just a guess. The spies win if the players are confused. Raising confusion isn't hard if you're a good player. In the end, there's a multitude of theories of who is and who isn't that it's just basically a hunch shot of who are spies. Played effectively, the spies are next to guaranteed a win, unless the resistance hits a real lucky streak. And I wouldn't ever play this with players who don't play effectively, hence it's senseless to play at all.

After two plays, my feelings were that this was just pure crap. Three more games and I was still convinced. I was resistance 3 times and spy 2 times and it was the same story all five times: Theories on who was who popped up based on who voted yes/no for whatever constellation of participants, and later on, based on who had participated in what and if that failed/succeeded. About all of them made sense, so random accusasions and "gut feelings" flew through the air. By the third round, there were so many theories (that were all plausible) about who had bluffed when that there was nothing clear to go on. Round 4, when the spies needed 2 fails, was easy as pie for the spies, just vote down anything that doesn't fit, same for 5th round and voilà. Add to that that everyone was clever enough not to leave trails, and at the end, it was up to a max 25% guess for the resistance to win.

Utter piece of crap and waste of precious gaming time.
